Travellers will love the relaxed atmosphere in this friendly country town. Feast on great country fare at the hotel bistro near our Park. Throw a line in the Murrumbidgee or explore local attractions.

properties.name: Dalmeny Camp Ground
properties.description:
Dalmeny Campground is one of the most relaxed and beautiful campgrounds on Australia’s east coast, great for family holidays or just a quiet weekend away.

It has absolute beach frontage with stunning views over the ocean to the north stretching along Dalmeny Beach and Eurobodalla National Park to Potato Point. As one happy camper said, ‘you can check the surf from your bed’.
To the west, the campground overlooks the entrance to Mummaga Lake.

Dalmeny Campground provides a range of facilities and amenities to help make your stay more comfortable. Please find the list of amenities available to all guests: 
- Powered and unpowered sites
- Accessible (wheelchair)
- Hire equipment (firepits)
- Laundry with coin operated washing machines, clothes dryers and clothes lines
- Kiosk - ice and ice creams
- Reception
- Shower facilities
- Restroom facilities
- Playground and BBQ next door
- Large grassed park
- Dump point near amenities block
- Dishwashing sinks at amenities block
- Dogs welcome provided on a leash and well behaved

properties.name: BIG4 Colonial Holiday Park
properties.description: Located at the entrance to the beautiful seaside village of Harrington. We offer our guests a quiet escape on the Mid North Coast. We have cabins with options for all tastes and budgets - ranging from large modern villa to double studios. The camp area has large powered, unpowered & drive through sites serviced with a modern amenities block.

properties.name: City Lights Holiday Park
properties.description:
Sitting on 6 hectares under the starry skies of country New South Wales, City Lights Holiday Park is your gateway to Australia’s country music capital Tamworth and surrounds.

City Lights Holiday Park is located in South Tamworth a suburb of Australia’s country music capital Tamworth in the New England region of NSW.

Whether you are spending the day visiting The Big Golden Guitar and Country Hands of Fame park, enjoying a game of golf at Longyard Golf Course, or attending one of the world-renowned music festivals held in Tamworth each year, City Lights Holiday Park is a convenient base for your next stay in Tamworth
Located near:
The Big Golden Guitar – 1 minute
Australian Equine and Livestock Events Centre (AELEC) – 2 minutes
Tamworth Sports Dome – 4 minutes
Country Music Hands of Fame Park – 9 minutes
Tamworth Regional Airport – 16 minutes
Sydney – 4 hours 29 minutes

Features:
Swimming Pool
Recreation Room
Laundry Facilities
BBQ Facilities
Camp Kitchen
Free Wi-Fi
Pet Friendly (conditions apply)
Amenities Block
Accessible Facilities
Kiosk

properties.name: BIG4 Tweed Billabong Holiday Park
properties.description: An award winning holiday destination located just metres south of the QLD border at the southern end of the Gold Coast. When looking for a holiday in Tweed Heads we will offer a experience like no other! Amazing facilities in a relaxed environment with accommodation options to suit all families. The perfect place to stay for a week or a month.

properties.name: NRMA South West Rocks Holiday Resort
properties.description:
A family escape in nature
Family togetherness has always been at the heart of South West Rocks. Located on the lands of the Dunghutti, this area is a special place that was host to gatherings of several nations for millennia. The spirit of togetherness continues at South West Rocks Holiday Resort, where your family is always welcome. And with everything you need for fun, adventure and relaxation right here, this is a family gathering made easy.

The kids will be out of your hair at our year-round kids’ club or our famous waterpark, leaving you to hit the pool with a book or grab a drink from the café. Later, watch live music together as a family, feast on local delights from a food truck or cuddle up for a movie under the stars. These are precious memories created in a place made for quality time.

properties.name: BIG4 Saltwater @ Yamba Holiday Park
properties.description: BIG4 Saltwater @ Yamba is a top rated holiday park set on 130 acres of pristine parkland just 10 minutes from the beautiful beach side town of Yamba. The park offers an amazing holiday experience with a unique combination of nature & facilities for the whole family. If you're keen for a holiday to remember, BIG4 Saltwater will certainly deliver.

properties.name: BIG4 Narooma East's Holiday Park
properties.description: Experience the best of both worlds! Being located on the edge of the pristine waters of the Wagonga Inlet and situated in the centre of Narooma township gives us a unique opportunity to offer you a magical holiday. A mix of fun, relaxation and nature's wonders at the park while in walking distance to Narooma’s retail and delicious food experiences.

properties.name: Tasman Holiday Parks - Ballina
properties.description:
If you want to kick back, soak up the sun and explore some of the most spectacular beaches on the NSW north coast, you've come to the right place!

Perched on the headland at glorious Skennars Head, our family-first caravan park offers the best of both worlds.

Relax in the tranquil surrounds of this natural haven. Then head off to discover the attractions of world-famous Byron Bay, only 20 minutes away or the colourful coastal vibe of Ballina and Lennox Head, just around the corner.

Be as connected, or off the radar as you like. With outstanding facilities for pleasure seekers of every age -  including free WiFi,  you won't be disappointed.

properties.name: BIG4 Albury Tourist Park
properties.description: BIG4 Albury Tourist Park is the closest caravan park to Albury's CBD, just 300 metres from Lavington Centro Shopping Centre, a variety of restaurants, cafes and retail outlets. It's the ideal location to base yourself at when discovering the beautiful Albury Wodonga region.

properties.name: Ingenia Holidays Nepean River
properties.description:
The Blue Mountains might be famous for clean, mountain air, but in its foothills, it’s also famous for fun, when you check into Ingenia Holidays Nepean River.

Backing onto the Nepean River, the park has accommodation options to suit every format of traveller with both families, couples and sporting enthusiasts making tracks to its Emu Plains location.

With a menu of cabins that range from 2 to 12 guests and cottages, camping and caravan sites in between, there’s plenty of space to settle into holiday-mode at Ingenia Holidays Nepean River.

properties.name: Ingenia Holidays Hunter Valley
properties.description:
If your idea of a good time is being surrounded by friends named Shiraz, Merlot and Chardonnay, pay a visit to Ingenia Holidays Hunter Valley where you’ll stay smack-bang in the middle of New South Wales’ favourite wine country.

Enjoy a grape escape at our holiday park which sits amongst no fewer than 150 cellar doors, all scattered across the Hunter Valley’s rolling green lawn hills, which support both the thriving viticulture and food scene found here.

By making Ingenia Holidays Hunter Valley your base, you’ll be staying at the perfect jumping off point to explore the region’s vineyards, cheese factories and chocolate shops – perfect for stocking up your home-away-from-home pantry.

When you don’t feel like cooking in your caravan, campsite, poolside villa, budget cabin or any of the BBQ or kitchen facilities onsite in between, you’re in luck – the Hunter Valley’s restaurants are all within a short drive’s distance of your holiday-door.

It’s not all wining and dining, the historic Wollombi and Morpeth are all within a short distance of the park too.

Inside the park, un-WINE-d among the park facilities which include a resort-style swimming pool, jumping cushion, restaurant, café and camp kitchen.

properties.name: Lake Burrinjuck Leisure Resort Woolgarlo Yass
properties.description:
Lake Burrinjuck is breathtaking setting to relax and enjoy a myriad of recreational activities,  water sports, fishing , bird watcher's paradise home of the beautiful King Parrot .

Popular with visitors and locals, , home to the famous Murray Cod, as well as Golden Perch (yellow belly) , red fin and European carp are targeted on a regular basis

The resort offers  a 3 bedroom house, cabins, cottages, ( own Linen required) powered and un-powered camping sites. A shop ,Bottle shop ,  Wooly"s Cafe(open Fridays and Saturdays ) games room, Fuel Sales and a pool to relax by.

properties.name: Kew Driver Reviver
properties.description: Free Overnight parking spot next to the Kew Information Center. Clean flush toilets and lots of space for Campervans, Caravans and Motorhomes.

properties.name: NRMA Stockton Beach Holiday Park
properties.description:
Discover a beachside getaway like no other in one of the most unique natural environments in Australia. NRMA Stockton Beach Holiday Park is tucked up against the Stockton Bite Sand Dunes in Worimi Conservation Lands. Here, 32km of ever-shifting sand dunes are waiting to be explored by 4×4, quad bike and even camel. Whatever your mode of exploration one thing’s for sure: this will be an unforgettable adventure in a place made for making memories.

Back at camp, you’ll find everything you need for an easy and relaxing holiday, from caravan and camping sites just metres from the beach to cabins with space for the family. Our communal cooking areas set the scene for fun-filled evenings under the stars with family and friends, while a quick ferry ride takes you to the heart of cosmopolitan Newcastle.

properties.name: Discovery Parks - Lane Cove Sydney
properties.description:
Escape the hustle and bustle of city life with an oasis getaway - only 10km from Sydney’s CBD! Discovery Parks - Lane Cove has everything you need to switch off from the daily grind and tune in to total relaxation. 

Pull out a picnic rug and share a sanga at one of the many picturesque picnic spots, or sleep under the stars in one of our luxurious Glamping Tents.

properties.name: Lachlan Shire Visitor Information Centre
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Warialda Heritage & Visitor Information Centre
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Harden Murrumburrah Visitor Information Centre
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Cootamundra Visitor Information Centre
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Junee Visitor Information Centre
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Wellington Visitor Information Centre

properties.name: Byron Bay 15000Ft Tandem Skydive
properties.description:
Enjoy the sensation of a 60 second free fall with a scenic tandem skydive over Byron Bay, an area surrounded with lush rainforest, mountains and golden beaches – the perfect scenic environments to skydive over! Operating for over 20 years this reputable skydive team boasts a 100% safety record so you KNOW that you are in safe hands!

Enjoy the moment and the views at up to 15,000ft before you plummet at over 200kph towards the beautiful coastline of Byron Bay. Even if you aren’t jumping, there is plenty to keep you entertained in the hangar, and you can even stand and watch near the drop zone to see your buddies coming in to land to share in the pure exhilaration that will be evident by the look of sheer excitement on their face!

This Byron Bay tandem skydive is a truly breathtaking experience – one to tick off the bucket list that’s for sure!

[Book for Weekday](https://experiencesau.campermate.com/en/byron-bay/byron-bay-tandem-skydive)

[Book for Weekend](https://experiencesau.campermate.com/en/byron-bay/byron-bay-skydive)

properties.name: Canowindra Age Of Fishes Museum
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Forbes Visitor Information Centre
properties.description: Make the Forbes Visitor Information Centre your first stop for a warm welcome and local knowledge and information on Forbes and the surrounding area. The friendly staff can provide you with a range of information on the "must see and do" local attractions, amazing upcoming events, and accommodation and dining options to suit the nature of your visit. The centre offers a selection of souvenirs, books and other merchandise items - take home a little piece of your time in Forbes. The Ben Hall Room is also open for viewing - brush up on Ben Hall's family history, check out artefacts discovered from the time of his reign, and watch the short film on his capture. A re-enactment filmed a few decades ago, but which will give you just that little bit more insight into the story of the infamous bushranger.

properties.name: Poplar Tourist Park
properties.description:
Poplars Tourist Park: Your Tranquil Escape in Camden, NSW

Relax and unwind at Poplars Tourist Park, a haven for nature lovers and travellers situated in beautiful Camden, New South Wales. We offer a variety of comfortable accommodation options and excellent facilities to ensure an unforgettable getaway in the picturesque Macarthur region.

properties.name: Discovery Parks - Pambula Beach
properties.description:
Wake up and smell the... surf? That's right, Discovery Parks – Pambula Beach is your scenic haven tucked inside Beowa National Park. 

Discover Discovery Parks – Pambula Beach, a coastal retreat nestled within Beowa National Park.

Enjoy secluded hiking trails and pristine beaches right at your doorstep. On-site, there’s plenty to keep you busy with a waterpark, resort-style pool, mini-golf, river kayaking, and oyster-hunting.

Located on the Sapphire Coast, our beachfront accommodation offers stunning views and easy access to the park’s natural wonders, including sparkling lakes, rugged bays, and surf beaches.

Choose from a range of options, from Deluxe 2-Bedroom Spa Cabins to spacious powered and unpowered ensuite sites, just steps from the sand.

properties.name: Yildaan Trail Campgrounds
properties.description:
Please speak to Shane for all booking enquiries - Click the phone link below

A unique family-friendly campground in the hinterland behind Coffs Harbour.  Great amenities and opportunities for bushwalking, swimming and mountain biking.
Caravans need to be self-contained, with no dump point.
Good mobile phone reception.  
Smoking is not encouraged due to cigarette butts. 

Non-aggressive pets or boisterous children under 15 free.

Power is available on request.

Weddings birthdays Schools clubs and functions POA .

"not just a campsite, a destination"

properties.name: Yuin Cultural Stories on Self Guided E-Bike Tour
properties.description:
Your self guided tour takes you to the Bar Rock Lookout. This is where you will stop for 45 minutes to meet with our Yuin Nation guide. With views to Gulaga and Baranguba from here the Yuin stories are all the more poignant. 

We cannot emphasise enough how a trip to Narooma and Tilba would not be complete without connecting the Yuin culture to this area of such intense natural beauty and cultural significance. 

Continue on a self guided e-bike tour to experiene this beautiful region.

properties.name: Wyanga Malu - Half Day Sydney Sightseeing Tour
properties.description:
Enjoy a living Dreamtime cultural trail of experiences including visiting sites of significance, rock engravings, and fauna and flora across metropolitan Sydney and the surrounding landscape to learn how Aboriginal people maintain their cultural connection. Experience first hand how to always walk on and travel through country, whether in the city or the outback, with a deep respect. 

Aboriginal guides will demonstrate how this place, we now know as Sydney, continues to weave the Dreamtime Southern X text into its modern, built up environment. Discover how to experience contemporary Aboriginal society right in the heart of cosmopolitan Sydney today.

properties.name: Wayapa Wuurrk Women's Full Moon Gathering
properties.description: Join Wayapa Wuurrk practitioner Dharawal woman Jaz Corr in sharing ancient Indigenous wisdom that focuses on taking care of the Earth as the starting point for creating Earth Mind Body Spirit Well-being.A practice and gathering of harmony within the environment, through a combination of Earth mindfulness, narrative meditation, a series of physical movements. Wayapa provides a sense of belonging to the Earth while creating holistic well-being.

properties.name: Warakirri Dining Experience Mudgee
properties.description:
Over four hours, enjoy Australian native food and beverages, prepared in a unique fusion of modern techniques with traditional methods. 

Be transformed by authentic cultural entertainment, musical and cultural storytelling, and the in-depth knowledge of Aboriginal culture and food, pioneered by owner and Ngemba Weilwan woman, Sharon Winsor.

properties.name: Taste of Wiradjuri Culture - Aboriginal Cultural Tour
properties.description:
Learn about the oldest people in the known universe, a living culture that is over 60,000 years old and that is still continuing to thrive.

On this tour you'll experience places and items of Wiradjuri significance. Visit Kengal, the Murrumbidgee River and Wagga Wetlands (weather permitting). 

Learn about Wiradjuri language and culture, see practical demonstrations of the art of traditional tool making and learn about special places and trees.

properties.name: One Hour Quad Bike Adventure Tour
properties.description: Live the adventure! Sand Dune Adventures promises you a quad riding experience like no other. Experience the magnificence of the Worimi Sand Dunes on Stockton Beach, riding safely from bush to beach with our expert guides. Our one hour quad bike ride takes in the wonders of the highest sand dunes in the southern hemisphere, the glorious views of the sweeping coastline and learn about history of the land.

properties.name: Mount Yengo Sunset Tour
properties.description: Come with us to hear the little lore stories. These are the very beginning stories of our Ngurrumpa (our camp world) as given to us by our Elders. These stories teach us how we should be and relate to all things around us. Wollombi has been, for millennia, an important meeting place to which Aboriginal people would travel for trade, social gatherings, and ceremony. This experience offers an opportunity to witness Mt Yengo, as sacred to Aboriginal People as Uluru is to the Central Desert people

properties.name: Mount Yengo Full Day Tour
properties.description: Enjoy a full day experiencing World Heritage Listed Yengo National Park, in the Hunter Valley region of New South Wales. Leanne King is a proud Dharug woman and she will share Wollombi cultural lore with you as you explore Finchley Trig, the Map Site and the Turkey Site at Mount Yengo. Learn about how Mount Yengo came to be and how it is considered as sacred to Aboriginal people of NSW as Uluru is to the central desert people.

properties.name: Full Day Gumbaynggirr Cultural Tour
properties.description:
Enjoy a full day starting with a stand up paddle tour followed by a cultural walking tour. 

This 4.5 hour cultural tour takes guests on an experience which allows them to learn Gumbaynggirr stories, language and bush tucker from the stunning creek and cultural significant walking locations. 

Throughout the day, learn simple phrases and the origin of Gumbaynggirr language, follow a traditional Dreaming story, sample bush food delicacies and engage with the resilience of Gumbaynggirr culture.

properties.name: Bush Tucker Walk Federal
properties.description: The Australian bush is full of edible fruits, roots, nuts, seeds and leaves. For centuries Aboriginal people have gathered, hunted and harvested this bush tucker. Delta Kay has lived on Country all of her life, she is a proud Arakwal custodian and is committed to working in genuine partnership with our local community to promote an awareness, understanding and mutual respect between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people. Delta’s stories have been handed down from her mother and her aunties.

properties.name: Burrawa Indigenous Bridge Climb
properties.description:
Scale the Sydney Harbour Bridge and discover fresh perspectives on the city below with an Indigenous Storyteller as your guide. 2 decades ago thousands of Australians walked across the Sydney Harbour Bridge in the name of reconciliation. 

Now is your chance to scale to the summit with an Indigenous Storyteller as your guide. With a view that is celebrated around the world, this special event offers a rare opportunity to broaden our understanding and appreciation of the harbour city.

properties.name: Bulgandry Aboriginal Walking Tour
properties.description:
Walk in the footsteps of Australia's first people and feel their living connection to the 21st century. Hear timeless stories, see original rock carvings and feel the power of connecting with this beautiful country. 

During the tour your guide will share stories and ancient knowledge that provide valuable insight into Bulgandy and the surrounding area. 

Witness a traditional Acknowledgement of Country, hear our creation story and participate in a traditional smoking ceremony.

properties.name: Aboriginal Tour Cape Byron
properties.description: During our tours, Delta Kay will share significant places and you will hear local history and traditional stories. Learn Bundjalung language and about bush food, natural medicine, tools, weapons and artifacts. Hear about Aboriginal existence before colonisation, including land preservation practices and learn the devastating impact of settlement and displacement on Aboriginal people. From coastal rainforest to crashing waves and rocky cliffs, the views on this tour are truly special.

properties.name: SeaChange Parks Conjola
properties.description:
CLOSED DURING MAY - AUGUST 2024.  

SEACHANGE MILTON IS OPEN AS USUAL!


SeaChanges Parks Lake Conjola is a picturesque 3 hour drive south of Sydney and a quick 2 hour trip from the heart of Canberra – this is a haven for your next lakeside family holiday!

Looking for a beach side escape? Check out our sister park Seachange Parks Milton.

properties.name: The Steps Barrington Campground
properties.description:
Nestled beneath the 600 metre peak of Mount Prince Charlie in the lush Barrington River valley, The Steps Barrington is a camping destination of spectacular natural beauty. At this splendid riverside location next to
The Steps rapids, you can relive the best of your childhood camping experiences with an uncrowded campground, unspoilt river vistas and friendly wildlife.

The Steps Barrington Campground is an authentic camping experience with year round appeal. The bushland setting of this boutique campground is easily accessed by two wheel drive vehicles and the numbers of campers allowed onsite is limited to ensure you have plenty of space and the natural environment is not stressed either.  It's just a short drive from the town centre of Gloucester NSW. 

In addition to our camp zones, we offer the self-contained Riverview Cottage. It sleeps up to 8 people in contemporary comfort. Find more information on our website https://www.thestepsbarrington.com.au/

properties.name: Talbingo Tourist Caravan Park
properties.description:
Experience a relaxing escape at Talbingo Tourist Caravan Park, nestled amidst the stunning Snowy Mountains. Ideally situated on the edge of Kosciuszko National Park and overlooking Jounama Pondage, the park offers a perfect basecamp for exploring the natural wonders of the region.
Whether you're seeking a family-friendly getaway or a romantic escape, Talbingo Tourist Caravan Park provides the ideal setting to unwind and connect with nature.

Book your stay today and experience the beauty of the Snowy Mountains!

properties.name: SeaChange Parks Milton
properties.description: We are ideally located a short drive from the historic township of Milton, close to Mollymook Beach and the township of Ulladulla. SeaChange Parks is a lush, green getaway and we are in the middle of 17 acres of gorgeous parkland

properties.name: Secret Lake Retreat
properties.description: Secret Lake Retreat is a small family-run business that provides lakeside and bush sites for swags, tents, caravans, motorhomes and anything in-between!

properties.name: Yengo Aboriginal Walking Tour
properties.description:
Following your guide, drive to stunning Finchley Trig Lookout for a traditional Acknowledgement of Country and to hear our story of creation. 

Here you will have a 360-degree view overlooking Mt Yengo which is as significant to local people as Uluru is to its people. 

Your guide will show you engravings and share ancient knowledge. Participate in a smoking ceremony, to protect and cleanse the mind and body. You will also hear language through story, song, and dance.

properties.name: Wiradjuri Motor Cycle Tour Full Day
properties.description:
Learn about the oldest people in the known universe, a living culture that is over 60,000 years old and that still continues to thrive.

Experience places and items of significance along a guided tour with Wiradjuri man Mark Saddler. Visit many significant places and sites, learn about bush tucker and native animals and take in valuable education about Wiradjuri country, people and ancient culture. 

Enjoy the road less travelled and see some of the most amazing aspects of Wiradjuri country.

properties.name: Tread Lightly Two World Cultural Tour
properties.description: Join us for a full day tour exploring the stunning south coast of New South Wales. and pend the morning with one of our Yuin Nation Elders. Begin your tour in Tilba Tilbaon one of the area's oldest farms then continue to Central Tilba where you will meet another one of our specialist guides for a historical walking tour and learn about the mining days in the 1800s and the unique history of this National Trust Village.

properties.name: Three Day Cultural Immersion Camp
properties.description:
Bring your swag for a three day, two night immersion camp with Leanne staying in Wollombi based at "Ngurrumpa", a 160 acre bush property close to Yengo National Park, in the Lower Hunter Valley, NSW. This is the traditional country of the Darkinjung people. 

Camp activities could include guided visits to various cultural sites, artefact making in wood and stone, traditional dance workshops and Corroboree, campfire stories and Aboriginal astronomy, traditional fibre-craft, bush walks including food and medicine discussions.

properties.name: illi-Langi The Rocks Aboriginal Dreaming Tour
properties.description:
Go on this ninety minute walkabout tour of illi-Langi, or The Rocks, in Sydney, and take a journey into the ways of life of the Aboriginal people. 

You'll learn about Dream Time and how the ancient culture is still alive in modern day Sydney from your Aboriginal guide. Start with an ocher activity, and then visit several areas around illi-Langi, The Rocks and learn about their Aboriginal significance.

properties.name: Pot to Plate Gourmet Cruise
properties.description: Private charter of the Pot to Plate Gourmet Cruise for your group. Onboard this exclusive 4 hour cruise, retrace the traditional hunting steps of the region's first inhabitants on the stunning Tweed River. Immerse yourself in this hands-on experience - hunt for mud crabs, pull up commercial crab pots, feed the pelicans and seabirds and try your luck at yabbie pumping before feasting on a sumptuous seafood harvest presented with the freshest Tweed produce.

properties.name: Gumbaynggirr Cultural Stand Up Paddle Tours
properties.description:
Our cultural stand up paddle experience takes our guests on a 2.5 hour paddle in picturesque and highly culturally significant marine park settings in the Coffs Harbour area -including Coffs Creek, Moonee, Red Rock and Corindi Old Camp. 

Your Aboriginal guide stops along the journey and allows guests to see and even taste seasonal bush tucker. 

Gumbaynggirr language is embedded in the content of the tour. Important traditional stories are told along the way as you stop through different sites.

properties.name: Giingan Gumbaynggirr Cultural Experience
properties.description:
The Giingan Experience is about Gumbaynggirr people, language and culture, taking place at an important cultural site the stunning location of Niigi Niigi (Sealy Lookout). 

Witness 360 degree views and immerse in our culture through stories, songs, language and the uses of native plants. Enjoy our Wajaarr Ngaarlu Dancers while tasting Aunty Jenny's damper. 

Walk down to Korora Lookout and hear the Dreaming stories of how the land was made to north.

properties.name: Bush Tucker Walk Mullumbimby
properties.description: The Australian bush is full of edible fruits, roots, nuts, seeds and leaves. For centuries Aboriginal people have gathered, hunted and harvested this bush tucker. Delta Kay has lived on Country all of her life, she is a proud Arakwal custodian and is committed to working in genuine partnership with our local community to promote an awareness, understanding and mutual respect between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people. Delta’s stories have been handed down from her mother and her aunties.

properties.name: Broken Head Aboriginal Tour
properties.description: During our tours, Delta Kay will share significant places and you will hear local history and traditional stories. Learn Bundjalung language and about bush food, natural medicine, tools, weapons and artifacts. Hear about Aboriginal existence before colonisation, including land preservation practices and learn the devastating impact of settlement and displacement on Aboriginal people. From coastal rainforest to crashing waves and rocky cliffs, the views on this tour are truly special.

properties.name: Bouddi Aboriginal Walking Tour
properties.description:
Walk in the footsteps of Australia's First People and feel their living connection to the 21st century. Hear timeless stories, see original rock carvings and feel the power of connecting to country. 

The park and surrounding area of Bouddi National Park contain more than 100 recorded Aboriginal sites. Hear stories, history and ancient knowledge that provide valuable insight into the surrounding area and witness a traditional smoking ceremony.

properties.name: Bingi Dreaming Track Cultural Walk
properties.description:
Learn all about the Aboriginal culture, history and Dreamtime stories unique to this area on a two hour walk with our respected local Aboriginal Yuin Nation guide. 

Walk along the stunning Bingi Dreaming Track, part of the Eurobodalla National Park. The tour is experiential and will see you taking part in a traditional smoking ceremony, learning about bush tucker, ancient sustainability practices and so much more.

properties.name: Bangalow Bush Tucker Tour
properties.description: Once an old grazing land, beautiful Bangalow Parklands and Byron Creek have been regenerated with hundreds of native plant species that are really important to Bundjalung people. During the tour, Delta points out a variety of these edible bush tucker plants, as well as plants used for natural medicine, jewellery, fibre, tools and weapons. She speaks about local Indigenous history and shares traditional stories that have been passed down to her from her ancestors.

properties.name: Island Leisure Village
properties.description: Set on a stunning lake front location at Port Stephens, the Island offers you a perfect place to relax, unwind and enjoy a great family holiday, escape the pressures of city life.

properties.name: Good Hope Resort
properties.description:
Good Hope Resort: Your Yass Valley Lakefront Escape

Escape to the idyllic surrounds of Good Hope Resort, a natural lakeside retreat located just 15 minutes from Yass in the beautiful Yass Valley region of NSW. Offering a range of comfortable accommodation options including cabins, caravan sites, and camping areas, Good Hope Resort is the perfect destination for a relaxing getaway or an adventure-filled break.

Relax by the sparkling swimming pool, soak up the stunning lake views, or cast a line for a spot of fishing. Explore the surrounding area with its rich fossil history, enjoy watersports on the lake, or go motorbike riding on designated trails. In the evenings, gather around the campfire and marvel at the incredible star-filled sky.

Book your stay at Good Hope Resort today and start planning your unforgettable NSW lakeside escape!

properties.name: Bonnie Vale Campground
properties.description:
Bonnie Vale is a family-friendly campground located between Bundeena and Maianbar at the north end of Royal National Park.

This popular riverside campground is known for its large sand spit, which makes it a great swimming spot.Whether you choose to pitch a tent or bring your caravan, youre sure to have a comfortable stay at Bonnie Vale. The campground has a mix of powered and unpowered sites, and is equipped with flush toilets, hot showers and drinking water, so you wont need to rough it.

Go fishing at nearby Jibbon Beach, enjoy a barbecue by the sea or hike along Royal National Parks long list of walking tracks. On weekends, you can even hire a kayak and paddle in the Hacking River.

properties.name: Sheepstation Creek Campground
properties.description: Set up your campsite at Sheepstation Creek campground €” an ideal spot to relax and recharge among World Heritage-listed rainforest. Theres plenty of room, so its the perfect choice if youre travelling in a large group with kids who like lots of space to run around or on a driving tour with a caravan or motor home. Dont forget to bring your own firewood so you can cook up a camp dinner and relax by the fire..Be sure to walk one of the three tracks that leave from the campground €“ the easy Palm Forest walking track is a great option for children, while Rosewood loop and the Booyong walking track are longer day walks.Take a virtual tour of Sheepstation Creek campground captured with Google Street View Trekker.

properties.name: Boyd River Campground
properties.description:
Set on the banks of Morong Creek, Boyd River Campground offers a peaceful setting in an open forest. Tall snow gums tower above and during early morning and late afternoon some of their inhabitants - sugar gliders, brush-tail possums and tawny frogmouths can be seen. 

Wombats, wallabies and kangaroos sometimes join you in the campground. 

There's also a recycled timber day hut on site to provide shelter, rain or shine.

Whether you want to go bushwalking, ride mountain bikes, have a keen interest in landscape photography, or are just eager for a getaway, this is the perfect destination. 

The start of both the lookout and waterfall walks are nearby, and Boyd River loop cycling trail starts in the carpark.

The closest town to the campsite is Oberon, and you can stock up on supplies there.

properties.name: Gillards Beach
properties.description: Youll find this pretty campground nestled between the beach and the bush.  Suitable for caravans, motorhomes, tents and camper trailers; Gillards Beach campground is the perfect weekend getaway for families and small groups alike.When youve set up your campsite, theres plenty to do nearby. Take a refreshing walk along the sandy beach or set up stumps for a game of beach cricket. Remember to bring your fishing rod along €“ there are some great spots to sink a line and youll be able to cook your catch up for dinner on the camp barbecue.In the evening, be sure to keep your eyes peeled and have your torch handy; you might spot a potoroo or two €“ they look a little bit like a small kangaroo or bandicoot. When youre ready to retire for the evening, the sound of the waves crashing nearby is sure to lull you in to a peaceful sleep.

properties.name: Main Campground
properties.description: Who said outback camping has to mean roughing it? At Main Camp, you'll find good basic facilities, including an amenities block, barbecues and picnic tables. Plus, it's just a short drive to Mungo Visitor Centre, where you can access hot showers, flush toilets and a public phone, so all the creature comforts are within easy reach.With its 33 roomy sites, there's plenty of space for your caravan, as well as for those with camping trailers and tents. The campground's location close to the park's entry and several attractions makes it a convenient place to base yourself and soak up this fascinating ancient landscape.Spot kangaroos, fire up the barbecue and have an old-fashioned sing-along.  Immerse yourself in the area's rich Aboriginal history on a Discovery tour, or set out on the Grasslands Nature trail. And, of course, no visit is complete without a sunset visit to Mungo lookout. Located within walking distance of the campground, the Walls' extraordinary colours and captivating scenery are sure to remain in your mind's eye as you drift off to sleep.Take a virtual tour of Main campground captured with Google Street View Trekker.

properties.name: Dawsons Spring Campground
properties.description: This popular campground, perched on the side of a mountain just past the Mount Kaputar summit, offers everything you need to kick back and enjoy the best of the national park.Snow gums surround picnic spots with dedicated barbecues and a well-equipped amenities block. Bring your tent to relax in the shade during warm summer months, dont forget to pack your binoculars for some spectacular birdwatching.Bushwalkers will find much of interest here too, with several superb walking tracks nearby. Dawsons Spring nature trail loops from the bottom of the campground, and it connects with the summit walk with dazzling views during clear autumn days. The beautiful Bundabulla circuit walking track, crosses through sub-alpine environments of the Kaputar plateau. The headwaters of Horsearm Creek can be seen along Dawsons Spring nature trail, and provide excellent photo opportunities.

properties.name: The Pines Campground
properties.description: The Pines campground is only a stones throw from Blowering Reservoir and on the edge of Bogong Peaks Wilderness. Located in the northern precinct of Kosciuszko National Park, its a perfect spot for adventure-seekers who love to revel in the great outdoors.Pull up the van or boat beside the reservoir and set up camp. With so many options for outdoor activities, and a huge stretch of water to play on, its a great base for water sports including paddling, sailing, boating, waterskiing and fishing.As the sun goes down over the water, its time to stoke up the barbecue for a feast of fresh fish. Then kick back and settle in for a night around the fire under a blanket of stars.

properties.name: Rummery Park Campground
properties.description:
Rummery Park campground is a small but well-equipped spot for camping near Byron Bay and Lismore.

This campground, ideal for families, is the perfect place to base yourself if you want to enjoy the many fantastic trails within Whian Whian State Conservation Area and Nightcap National Park. From here, you can take a short walk along Boggy Creek track to the beautiful Minyon Falls lookout. You can also go car touring or birdwatching, or just sit back and enjoy a peaceful, relaxing camping experience.

Make friends with the kookaburras resting in the surrounding gum, pine and kauri trees - you might even spot a koala while you're looking. Other animals that visit the campground include goannas, lorikeets, and possums. When youre hungry, strike up one of the gas barbecues at Rummery Park campground.

properties.name: Bents Basin Campground
properties.description: Bents Basin offers a camping experience that is within easy reach of urban Sydney suburbs. Its an open, grassy campground bordered by trees on one side and featuring Bents Basin on the other.Take your pick of campsites, pitch your tent or bring your caravan or trailer along. Its a great choice whether you are going family camping or camping with a larger group.Once youve set up camp, what you do next is up to you; relax by the Basin, take a walk along Caleys lookout track, go for a paddle or try your hand at fishing, or if youre feeling hungry, start up the barbecue to cook your lunch.Youll find excellent facilities, including a camp kitchen ideal for group bookings and hot showers €“ a welcome luxury after a day exploring this park.

properties.name: Indian Head Campground
properties.description: Set on the western side of Diamond Head, Indian Head campground is a relaxed place to pitch a tent before your explorations of Crowdy Bay National Park begin. When your base camps established, its time to decide on your first adventure. A couple of the parks walking tracks leave from the campground, including the scenic Forest walk and the longer Diamond Head Loop walk.The beach is not far from the campground and is a great place for a spot of beach cricket or football. You might even see some of the parks birdlife, like jabirus and pied oystercatchers. Of an evening, you can hear the crash of the ocean and if you are lucky, you might see some of the parks kangaroos at dusk.Take a virtual tour of Indian Head campground captured with Google Street View Trekker.

properties.name: Trial Bay Gaol Campground
properties.description:
Trial Bay Gaol campground offers campsites for tents, caravans, campervans and camper trailers in an enviable position beside Front Beach.Pack your snorkels, swimmers, fishing rod, walking shoes and surfboard, because youll have time to use all of these when youre enjoying this delightful campground and picnic area. And if you're too tired after a day exploring the park to cook up a feast, treat yourself to a meal at the Trial Bay Kiosk Restaurant. It's the ideal place for families to take a weekend break in the beautiful Arakoon National Park. 

Thinking of going in winter? Make sure you take your binoculars - Arakoon is a great place to see whales making their annual migration north. And even better in spring as they make their way south hugging the coast and resting with their calves in Trial Bay, just off the campground.

properties.name: Lake Arragan And Red Cliff Campgrounds
properties.description: Lake Arragan and Red Cliff campgrounds sit side-by-side on the parks northern coastline. Between them, there are 90 grassy campsites €“ many with shade and all just a short walk from the beach.Choose a campsite at Lake Arragan, a small coastal lagoon system surrounded by paperbarks. This is a great spot for canoeing, swimming, fishing and birdwatching, and if youre feeling energetic, you can try the 10km coastal walk to Angourie.Or head south to Red Cliff for panoramic coastal views. Here you can discover isolated beaches or just listen to the surf roll over the rocks while watching kangaroos and birds going about their business.

properties.name: Tom Groggin Campground
properties.description: Tom Groggin campground is set on the banks of the upper Murray River, just off Alpine Way. Theres plenty of room for relaxed camping in open areas, in a lovely valley setting with stunning mountain and riverside backdrops.Located between Khancoban and Thredbo, its a great stop if youre touring Kosciuszko National Park and the surrounding high country areas by car. The weather conditions are also generally milder here in the valley than higher areas of Kosciuszko National Park.Tom Groggin campground makes a popular base camp for mountain bikers and bushwalkers tackling the iconic Bicentennial trail. You can also explore the huts of nearby Geehi, and take in the views from Scammells and Olsens lookouts. The year-round activities of Thredbo Alpine Village are only 25km east along Alpine Way.The open grasslands in the valley are home to a large population of resident eastern grey kangaroos. Emus, echidnas, brush-tailed possums, lyrebirds, flame robins and crimson rosellas can also be spotted.

properties.name: Wollomombi Campground
properties.description: Wollomombi campground is perfect for an overnight bush stop while exploring the falls country of New England by campervan. You might be tempted to stay a couple of days to admire the spectacular gorges and waterfalls of the World Heritage-listed Oxley Rivers National Park. Pull up to this peaceful bush campsite and take a short walk to explore Edgars lookout which is easily accessible. Enjoy a barbecue lunch or dinner using the facilities at Wollomombi Falls picnic area nearby. Work off your meal with a short but challenging walk along Chandler walking track and take in the majestic views over Wollomombi Falls. Brilliant after heavy rain, the moist air creates dazzling rainbows. If you're after slightly easier and longer path try Wollomombi walking track and be rewarded with views of picturesque Chandler Falls.Bring some binoculars for a spot of birdwatching. In the skies above, you might glimpse a wedge tailed eagle or the rare peregrine falcon. A little closer to ground the lyrebird will impress you with a flamboyant display.

properties.name: Fingal Bay Holiday Park
properties.description:
Surrounded by National Park and across the road from a patrolled surfing beach, the 3.5 star Fingal Bay Holiday Park is still just 5 minutes from the heart of Nelson Bay and a stones throw away from Shoal Bay. Fingal Bay Holiday Park offers all the convenience of a first class holiday resort in a stunning natural bushland setting. Go troppo in our resort pool, cook up a storm in the camp kitchen or stay in self contained luxury in one of our large family Beach Houses. 

You will appreciate this award winning park's facilities and ideal location with beach and bushwalking on your doorstep! 3 bedroom family villa apartments available with great views. We also have an accessible cabins, please enquire direct for more details.

Did you know that Fingal Bay Holiday Park is also a dog friendly park? However certain restrictions apply - Dogs are only permitted when staying in your own tent or caravan and not during peak periods & no pets are allowed during NSW Holiday Periods (with the exception of July School Holidays) and we do ask that you please check with us before bringing your dog. For more details call us on 02 4988 0990. We can also recommend some great kennels so you can still enjoy the area with your best friend during the day and he can sleep over at the kennels at night.

Important things to note: We don't charge extra to use the communal BBQ's, hot water or camp kitchen. We provide all linen, pillows and towels for FREE for the main bedroom (2 persons) when staying in a villa or cabin.(Linen packs for additional beds available at $15 per pack. Our rates include 2 adults and up to 3 children up to 17yrs of age. )

properties.name: Discovery Parks - Gerroa
properties.description:
Welcome to Discovery Parks – Gerroa, the ultimate holiday destination where the only thing you’ll regret is not bringing your camera. With a pool, bouncing pillow, and mini-golf, the park is perfectly located at the mouth of Crooked River and near Seven Mile Beach.

For thrill-seekers, visit Jamberoo Action Park, a fun blend of amusement and water park. Feeling adventurous? Walk 45 meters up on the Illawarra Fly Treetop Walk, or just go for it—you’re on holiday!

Check out the Kiama Blowholes, where water shoots up to 25 meters high, or enjoy a Dolphin Wild Cruise from Jervis Bay to see playful dolphins up close.

At Discovery Parks – Gerroa, you’ll experience a beautiful park and develop a whole new love for the great outdoors.

properties.name: Capital Country Holiday Park
properties.description: Capital Country Holiday Park is set on 40 picturesque acres and just 15 minutes to all of Canberra’s attractions and venues.

properties.name: Discovery Parks - Ballina
properties.description:
If you're craving a holiday that makes your worries float away like a rubber duckie on a lazy river, get yourself to Discovery Parks - Ballina. Nestled right next to the Richmond River, this place is a playground of chill and thrill.

Discovery Parks - Ballina provides a peaceful retreat with modern comforts, perfect for those looking to unwind and explore the natural beauty of the North Coast. The park offers a variety of accommodation options, including cabins and well-equipped camping sites, catering to both leisure travellers and adventurers. With its tranquil riverside setting and proximity to local attractions, it’s an ideal base for a relaxing getaway.

**Camping Facilities:**
For camping enthusiasts, Discovery Parks - Ballina offers a range of well-maintained camping facilities designed to ensure a comfortable stay. The park features spacious powered and unpowered sites, suitable for caravans, motorhomes, and tents. 

- The powered sites provide essential services like electricity and water, making them ideal for those traveling with caravans or motorhomes. 
- The unpowered sites offer a more traditional camping experience, set in lush, green areas that are perfect for pitching a tent. 

Each site is generously sized, providing ample space and privacy in a peaceful, natural setting.

**Amenities:**
- Well-appointed camp kitchen with cooking facilities, BBQs, and a communal dining area for meal preparation and enjoyment.
- Clean and modern bathroom facilities with hot showers and ample space.
- Laundry facilities with washing machines and dryers to keep your clothes fresh.
- Free WiFi available throughout the park to stay connected.

**Family-Friendly Features:**
Discovery Parks - Ballina is a family-friendly destination with plenty of activities to keep everyone entertained. The park boasts a resort-style swimming pool, ideal for a refreshing dip, and a children’s playground where kids can enjoy themselves in a safe environment. The park’s riverside location also provides opportunities for fishing, boating, and kayaking, making it a perfect spot for families who enjoy outdoor activities. The nearby beaches and walking trails offer additional opportunities for exploration and fun.

**Nearby Attractions:**
Ballina is a vibrant coastal town known for its stunning beaches, scenic river views, and laid-back atmosphere. The park is just a short drive from the famous Ballina Lighthouse and Shelly Beach, where you can enjoy swimming, surfing, or simply relaxing by the water. The nearby Richmond River offers excellent opportunities for fishing, boating, and exploring the local wildlife. For those interested in the arts and culture, the Ballina Naval and Maritime Museum is a must-visit, showcasing the rich maritime history of the region. The town center of Ballina is also within easy reach, offering a variety of shops, cafes, and restaurants to explore.

**Pet Policy:**
Pets are welcome on selected sites, but prior approval is required, and availability may be limited. Be sure to check the pet policy when making your reservation.

**Check-In/Check-Out:**
Guests are welcome to check in from 2:00 PM, with check-out by 10:00 AM on the day of departure.

properties.name: Stuart's Point Tavern
properties.description:
Free Motor vehicle stays welcomed. Bistro and bar available, public toilets inside the venue. Must organise with management for stays on 65690334. Pets welcome, kids room inside venue, wifi inside venue, fire place inside venue. We just ask that you be respectful of neighbours and customers.

Self contained vehicles only.

properties.name: Sheralee Tourist Carvan Park
properties.description: The Sheralee Tourist Caravan Park offers a variety of camping options

properties.name: Halfway Creek Rest Area
properties.description: This is a rest area with disability accessible non-flush toilets. You can pull into the parking area either side of the rest area. There are sheltered picnic tables, rubbish bins and non-potable hand washing water.

properties.name: Halifax Holiday Park
properties.description:
This award winning park is perfectly situated in the heart of beautiful Port Stephens. 

Choose from powered camp and van site, one bedroom standard cabins through to 3 bedroom luxury villas overlooking Shoal bay Beach. Set in natural bushland, surrounded by two calm water beaches, Shoal Bay and Little Beach Halifax Holiday Park is the ideal choice to have it all at your fingertips. 

This 4 star park is just 15 minutes stroll to the centre of Nelson Bay, with cafes, shops & restaurants. The park is a favourite for boating enthusiasts with a deep water boat ramp adjacent, calm waters and a marina close by. We are also a dog friendly park during non peak times and when you are staying in your own tent or van. *Please ask before bringing your dog as Managers discretion will apply.

Located in the heart of Port Stephens between two beautiful beaches, Little Beach & Shoal Bay - boasts crystal clear, water with white sandy shores & gentle waves. The Park has access to a boat ramp & marina nearby. Close to marinas, restaurants, shops & clubs. Accommodation ranging from campsites to luxury villas.

Dogs are permitted when staying on a tent or van site outside of school holiday periods at the discretion of Management. Due to OH&S regulations dogs are not allowed to occupy cabins or villas at any time.

properties.name: Cod Hole Campground
properties.description: For a remote wilderness adventure deep in the heart of Nymboi-Binderay National Park on the Dorrigo plateau, head for Cod Hole campground and picnic area. This rustic camping spot offers the chance to really get away from it all, in magnificent wild river country, surrounded by lush forests.Settle in to your campsite before heading to the river for a range of water-based activities. This river is best known for whitewater but when the river is relatively calm, head in for a swim. Rafting is a great way to explore and theres a range of guided tours on offer.Nymboi-Binderay is the Aboriginal name for €˜The mighty river, and the local Gumbaynggirr People would paddle these waters. Scarred trees, where canoes were carved from the trunks, are dotted throughout the park.As night settles in, cook up a storm over the fire. If youre curious to meet the neighbours, grab a torch for the chance to see sugar gliders, spotted quolls and bettongs.

properties.name: Broughton Island Campground
properties.description: Camping on Broughton Island is a truly special experience. Located in Myall Lakes National Park, you'll be camping amongst an active seabird colony- its a key breeding site for wedge-tailed shearwaters.There are plenty of opportunities for water activities, including swimming, fishing, boating, snorkelling and scuba diving. Youll find sandy beaches within Esmeralda Cove.With only five campsites, youll feel like you own the island. The campground is fairly basic, so youll have to bring all your equipment and supplies with you, including water. You must book and pre-pay for a campsite prior to arriving at the island.

properties.name: Six Mile Creek Campground
properties.description: Six Mile Creek campground is on the smaller side, featuring 6 campsites nestled amongst wet eucalypt forest. You can camp out in your tent or bring a camper trailer, theres room for both at this free campground.Follow the 300m Six Mile Creek walk €“ it leads you to a viewing platform overlooking cascading waters on their way to Tantawangalo Creek. Take a barbecue pack if you'd like to stop for lunch.If youre camping out on the first Sunday of the month, why not pop over to the riverside Candelo Market? Youll find something fascinating or flavourful among the many stalls.When youre on the road to or from Six Mile Creek campground, take in the history of the area €“ the original Tantawangalo Mountain Road leading to this site was forged around 1860.

properties.name: Lachlan River Campground
properties.description: Enjoy a tranquil camping holiday by the water at Lachlan River campground in Kalyarr National Park. Nestled between red river red gums and river cooba on the banks of the peaceful Lachlan River, its a secluded spot to get back to nature. Autumn and spring are the best seasons to camp here when its not too hot or windy.Once youve set up camp, theres plenty to see and do. Go fishing, swimming or paddling in the river or enjoy a picnic lunch next to Lake Ita. If youre eager to see more of the park, take a walk through riverside woodland and open plains along Kalyarr Cultural trail which starts from the campground.During your stay, keep an eye out for the iconic outback wildlife that call this place home. Red kangaroos, emus and shingle-back lizards are common in this area, and if you gaze to the skies, you might see wedge-tailed eagles soaring overhead.As evening falls, cook up a barbecue feast and enjoy the beautiful outback sunsets and uninterrupted 360-degree views of the starry sky.

properties.name: Edward River Bridge Campground
properties.description: Set on the picturesque Edward River in Murray Valley Regional Park, adjacent to Murray Valley National Park, Edward River Bridge campground is bush camping at its best.It's a great choice for a family camping holiday €“ being located in Murray Valley Regional Park, its dog-friendly, and its also free and suitable for caravans, motorhomes and tents. There's plenty to keep everyone happy €“ go for an energising walk on Gulpa Creek walk, barbecue at the neighbouring Edward River Bridge picnic area, or relax with a book under the shade of a river red gum. If you've brought your fishing gear along, there are plenty of great spots to cast your line along the river and some good places for swimming, not to mention opportunities to paddle Edward River canoe and kayak trail and bike ride.Remember to bring your binoculars, as this part of the park is great for birdwatching €“ head to Reed Beds Bird Hide boardwalk in the nearby Murray Valley National Park for the best opportunities to see migratory birds.The town of Mathoura isn't far away if you need to pick up some camping supplies or want to start the day reading the paper over a cappuccino.

properties.name: Thungutti Campground
properties.description: Nestled under the shade of the tall eucalypt trees, youll find plenty of tucked away and secluded campsites to pitch a tent at Thungutti campground.Relax and enjoy the lush greenness of scattered ferns around you, listening to the kookaburras laughing in the trees above.Once you get settled, its time to explore. Tea Tree Falls walking track starts right here, taking you through tea tree woodland and across the Styx River headwaters to a forest of hanging moss. Or head off on Eagles Nest walking track to discover the incredible natural wonders of the ancient Gondwana rainforest.On your return, youll find a barbecue shelter for cooking up a tasty dinner and a place to enjoy the warmth of the campfire. Then, snuggle up for a good nights rest, before your sunrise visit to Point lookout.

properties.name: Nunnock Campground
properties.description: Located in South East Forest National Park, between Bega and Cooma, this small campground has room for 3 tent sites and 1 camper trailer or caravan. Surrounded by forest, biodiverse swamps and grasslands, it will delight campers, bushwalkers, wildlife spotters and photographers.Set up your tent or camper then get ready to explore. Nunnock Swamp and Grasslands walking tracks are a great place to start, with 15km of trails taking in this areas nature and history.Walk the 4km trail fringing this rare upland swamp to pass through tall wet forest, dry forest and grasslands that burst with flowers in spring and summer. See wedge-tailed eagles soar overhead, while Wilkinsons leek orchids, native bluebells, and swamp paper daisies peek out from the ground at your feet.The short, moderate Keys walking track leads from the campground, through grassland and snow gum woodland, and into pastoral history. At Keys Stockyards see wallabies graze where cattle once fed. Continue along Wilkinsons walking track to discover rustic Alexanders Hut, built for yesteryears cattlemen.Back at camp, cook up a hearty meal around the campfire as nightfall brings the chance to see ringtail possums, wombats and, if you're lucky, greater gliders.

properties.name: Deniliquin Campground
properties.description: For a real taste of peaceful solitude, book a camping stay at Deniliquin campgrounds on the Edward River. Choose from 3 campgrounds when you arrive:     Willoughbys Beach campground     Muna / Lagoon campground    Lip-Lip-Wil / Yabby campgroundCampsites are suitable for tents, caravans and motorhomes, and it's a great camping spot for the whole family to enjoy. You can even bring your dog along to join in the fun, thanks to its location in Murray Valley Regional Park.If you're looking for a little fix of the outside world during your stay, there's a sealed track that meanders along Edward River to nearby McLeans Beach in town, so you can easily wander into Deniliquin for a coffee and to collect the daily paper.There's plenty to do in the park €“ try your hand at a spot of fishing and be sure to bring your bikes along to explore the park's trails. You can also put your boat into Edward River using the easily accessible boat ramp, best suited for small to medium vessels.

properties.name: Old Snowy Campground
properties.description: Visit this lovely, quiet campground in Kosciuszko National Park and find out why time spent in the unspoilt beauty of the Snowy Mountains region is the ultimate stress-reliever.Nestled beside Gurrangorambla Creek and sheltered by black sallee gums, Old Snowy campground offers invigorating valley views, along with frequent visits from kangaroos and wallabies.Bush surroundings, unmarked sites and rudimentary facilities are all part of the campgrounds back-to-basics charm. Set up your tent or trailer and then head off on a bushland mountain bike ride, exploring the northern end of Currango Plain. Bushwalking is a treat in this scenic area, too, so why not come in spring to wander through the wildflowers?Old Snowy campground is ideal if you want to combine camping with horse riding. Youll find convenient, dividable horse yards, and its a great starting point for the heritage-packed Pocket Ride.Birdwatchers, too, are in for a treat with thrushes, treecreepers and currawongs in abundance. And if a spot of trout fishing takes your fancy, youre well-catered for in the nearby creeks and streams of Kosciuszko National Park.

properties.name: Turon River Camping
properties.description: This campground is suitable for tents and 4WD camper trailers.Bookings are required. Book online or call the National Parks Contact Centre on 1300 072 757.

properties.name: The Ruins campground
properties.description:
From rugged campers to casual caravaners, The Ruins Campground offers the perfect escape for all types of visitors. Nestled in a picturesque setting, surrounded by cabbage tree palms and paperbarks, the campground provides all the essentials—picnic tables, barbecues, hot showers, and drinking water. But what truly sets it apart is its proximity to stunning natural attractions.

Don't forget your swimmers—whether you’re drawn to the surf or prefer the calm of a sheltered lake, both are just a stone’s throw away. Seven Mile Beach is a beautiful stretch of sand and offers excellent whale watching in winter. Nearby, Wallis Lake invites relaxation beneath the trees or a leisurely kayak paddle on its serene waters.

For those who enjoy a bit of adventure, the Booti Hill and Wallis Lake walking track offers scenic lookouts and connects directly to Elizabeth Beach, known for great surfing and seasonal lifeguard patrols. Keep an eye out for graceful shorebirds along the challenging trail.

If you’re in the mood for something more laid-back, you’ll find cafes in Pacific Palms just a short drive away, making it easy to unwind with a coffee and a newspaper. Whether you seek adventure or relaxation, The Ruins Campground is the ideal spot to recharge.

properties.name: Willis Campground
properties.description: Bookings are required. Book online or call the National Parks Contact Centre on 1300 072 757.

properties.name: Aragunnu Campground
properties.description: This large campground features 4 distinct camping areas, so bring your tent or camper trailer and take your pick of campsite setting: untamed surroundings just 50m from the beach, an open, grassy area shaded by tall coastal mahogany, or an elevated spot to the west of the beach.Theres easy access to walking tracks at Aragunnu campground. Head to Aragunnu Beach and explore its own unusual stones €“ some of which are as tall as a child and youll find good fishing spots nearby, as well as two picnic areas. Be sure to take the Mimosa Rocks walk that takes you past one of the parks Aboriginal sites, before leading on to a scenic lookout.

properties.name: Buddong Falls Campground
properties.description: For a weekend getaway far from the crowds, pack up the 4WD and head for Buddong Falls campground, in the remote north-west region of Kosciuszko National Park, near Talbingo township. This rustic creekside camping spot is close to picturesque waterfalls and walking tracks, ideal for independent campers seeking a tranquil haven.Set amongst tall forests of smooth-barked ribbon gums, pitch your tent before exploring the nearby creek and waterfall. If youre ready to stretch your legs, Buddong Falls walking track leads to two pretty waterfalls and forms part of the longer Hume and Hovell walking track.During the day, parrots and tree-creepers may be seen flitting amongst the branches. At night, settled in around a campfire, you might glimpse possums and gliders.

properties.name: Little Beach Campground
properties.description: The small but popular Little Beach campground offers beachfront tent camping ideal for surfers and nature-lovers. The campground is tucked into a pretty cove and surrounded by littoral rainforest. Its equipped with sheltered barbecues and toilets, but beyond that its just you and the great outdoors. Bring your surfboard to make the most of the early morning swell at Little Beach, or start the day with a swim and a wander along the beach's rocky shore. See if the fish are biting or pull on your hiking shoes there are several lovely walks to enjoy in the area, including the lovely Bouddi coastal walk. When the day is done and you're ready to relax, cook up a feast on the free gas barbecues while the sun sets and share stories about your spectacular day at Little Beach. Take a virtual tour of Little Beach campground captured with Google Street View Trekker.

properties.name: Big River Campground
properties.description: Retreat to nature by pitching your tent at Big River campground. Located at the end of Big River drive, the campground is the perfect getaway set amongst the trees above the Goulburn River.The whole family will enjoy plunging into the waterholes along the river for a swim. Explore the sandstone caves and overhangs that follow the river. As the sun goes down, fire up the barbecue and cook up a hearty meal, watch the kangaroos grazing and prepare for another exciting day.

properties.name: Carrington Falls Campground
properties.description: If youre planning to visit the spectacular Carrington Falls waterfall, this small and simple campground next to the Kangaroo River is a tranquil spot to set up camp.For a morning stroll, make your way to Izzards lookout which rewards you with views of the lush forest below. Or stretch your legs on the longer Missingham lookout and Warris Chair lookout walking tracks for front-on views of the deep gorges of Carrington Falls.Spring is an ideal time to drop in, with pops of yellow and red native flowers blooming in the bloodwood forest. If youre camping in the warmer months, slip on your swimmers and take the plunge in one of the nearby swimming holes.

properties.name: 1St Bay Campground
properties.description: 1st Bay campground can comfortably fit 6 to 8 people, but is best suited to a single family. It has 1 wood barbecue and no other facilities. The only way to reach this campground is by boat along Warrell Creek. You can leave your car at Weir Reserve, Scotts Head or near the boat ramp at Stuart's Island, accessed via  Bellwood Park on Riverside Drive. These areas are not part of the Gaagal Wanggaan National Park €“ parking is unmonitored and at your own risk.There are no camping fees at this campground, but a $6 booking fee applies. Bookings are required. Book online or call the National Parks Contact Centre on 1300 072 757.

properties.name: Mooraback Campground
properties.description: Escape the crowds and get back-to-basics in this small, isolated campground tucked among the snow gums.Take your pick from the grassy campsites to set up your tent; the campsites are spread out so youll barely notice other campers. Your only company is likely to be eastern grey kangaroos and red-necked wallabies coming to graze in the afternoons.Stroll along Mooraback walking track, a short loop walk from the campground. Or wander out to Platypus Pools in the upper reaches of Hastings River and see if you can spot a platypus or two.At night, enjoy a barbecue dinner, sit by the warmth of a campfire and listen to the sounds of the bush. When you wake the following morning, you'll emerge from your tent - most likely to a beautiful frost - and can prepare for another day of adventure.

properties.name: Bummaroo Ford Campground
properties.description: Get away from city life at the riverside Bummaroo Ford campground. This family-friendly camping spot is the only place in Abercrombie River National Park where you can bring your caravan or trailer.Take a hike along the Abercrombie River, but take your swimmers with you €“ when the weathers warm and the water levels are high, youll definitely want to take a dip. Its also a great place for paddling if youve got a canoe or kayak.During the spring, the beautiful golden wattles and red and yellow callistemons (bottlebrushes) along the river come into flower, bringing feeding birds with them. Its certainly a time of new life around here €“ its also the season youll hear frogs singing by the water. All year round, youre likely to see kangaroos and wallabies near the campsite. Sit quietly by the waterholes at dusk and you might also see a platypus.

properties.name: Long Gully Campground
properties.description: Long Gully campground, like Budawang in general, is one for experienced travellers. Located on a grassy flat beside Yadboro River, surrounded by blackbutt trees and rising steeply on the northern side, this is a place you come to get away from everything. Facilities are minimal €“ pit toilets and picnic tables, with no marked sites €“ but the sort of person who comes here is self-sufficient and hardy. Plus, the scenery is spectacular.Bring the tent, firewood, and enough food to last (water can be collected from the river and boiled), then settle down in scenic solitude. The remoteness of Long Gully means your closest neighbours are likely to be goannas and wallabies, though there is an adjacent picnic area. Avid bushwalkers will want to pack their hiking boots and compass as well for an exhilarating walk in the Budawang backcountry. The arduous trek to the Castle also begins from here, suitable for well-equipped adventurers only.Wherever you end up, return to a refreshing splash in Yadboro, though better swimming opportunities can be found in nearby Clyde River. Dont forget your towel.

properties.name: Hungry Gate Campground
properties.description: Hungry Gate campground is located at the southern end of Hat Head National Park. The area has an open, spacious feel but is protected from the elements by sand dunes and surrounded by thick vegetation. You can bring your tent or camper trailer to Hungry Gate, which sits 30km north east of Kempsey and 32km south of Nambucca Heads.Take time to admire the established fig trees and paperbarks behind the dunes and youll be rewarded €“ theyre home to a variety of birdlife. Brahimy kites often fly over the beach, just a 20-minute walk away. The parks kangaroos are fond of the campground and graze there regularly. Youll also see little bent winged bats and well-fed goannas.

properties.name: Barokee Campground
properties.description: Campsites at Barokee campground are tucked away amongst tall banksia and eucalyptus trees, giving a lovely sense of privacy. And because this is remote camping, youre more than likely to have the place to yourself.Located in the central section of Cathedral Rock National Park, the campground is the closest point to Cathedral Rock itself, so you can enjoy a trek along Cathedral Rock track or the longer Barokee to Native Dog Creek walk.The swampy valley at the head of Snowy Creek near Barokee is home to a variety of plants and wildflowers. Many of these flower in spring while some, such as orchids, and the pretty purple flowered coast mint bush at different times of the year. At the high altitude, alpine shrubs such as the alpine fan flower, bottlebrush and epacris thrive here.

properties.name: Black Swamp Campground
properties.description: This small and secluded camping spot is perfect for adventurous campers who love the opportunity to experience the remote and wild regions. Black Swamp campground, accessed via Aeroplane Hill walking track or Careys Peak walking track, is perched on the edge of a unique sub-alpine wetland, providing habitat for many unique plants and wildlife.The swamps of the high plateau of Barrington Tops National Park have been declared an endangered ecological community and protect many threatened species including the broad-toothed rat and the glandular frog.After a day of walking the trails of the high country, cook up a hearty meal, and enjoy a night in the pristine wilderness with the light of the stars and moon above. As you drift off to sleep, you might hear the call of the powerful owl ringing through the snowgums into your dreams.Take a virtual tour of Black Swamp campground captured with Google Street View Trekker.

properties.name: Dangars Gorge Campground
properties.description:
Dangars Gorge campground is a fabulous bush base for experiencing the rugged beauty of this World Heritage-listed falls country. You’ll be camping beside one of the most impressive waterfalls in NSW, on the edge of the Great Escarpment on the western edge of Oxley Wild Rivers National Park.

Once you’ve set up camp, check out the scenic waterfall lookout, spectacular sight after heavy rain as water cascades over a 120m drop shrouding everything in mist and creating beautiful rainbows. There’s a range of walks like the McDirtys walking track, so after a picnic lunch, pull on your walking boots and get ready to explore.

When the sun starts to go down, its time to barbecue up a feast before settling in round the campfire with a glass of your favourite drop and a night of stargazing.

properties.name: Holy Camp
properties.description: Holy Camp is a sheltered campground which offers a picnic area, walking track and a lookout with scenic views stretching over the sandstone outcrop of Weddin Range.Go bushwalking around Holy Camp, alive with mugga ironbarks, red stringybarks and black cypress pine. You might even hear the haunting call of the southern boobook and tawny frogmouth, as you drift off to sleep.There are opportunities to spot native wildlife such as red-necked wallabies, eastern grey kangaroos and brush-tailed possums. The area is also rich in birdlife, so if you enjoy birdwatching, pack your binoculars and look out for kookaburras, peregrine falcons, wedge-tailed eagles, turquoise parrots and speckled warblers, calling the area home.

properties.name: Burbie Camp
properties.description: Also known as Burbie Springs, this walk-in campground is a great stopover on a longer hike or perfect for a weekend of wildlife spotting and birdwatching. Accessed on foot along Burbie Canyon track and Burbie trail, Burbie Camp is located between iconic Mount Exmouth and Belougery Split Rock, in Warrumbungle National Park.When you arrive at your rustic campsite, take in the rugged mountain views and crystal clear air. Inhale deeply and savour the spicy cocktail scent of cypress pine, eucalypts, and the sticky daisy bush. At dusk, you might catch a glimpse of a swamp wallaby, red-necked wallaby, or wallaroo. The sight of a majestic wedge-tailed eagle soaring high on the cliff thermals is an inspiring sight which adds to the atmosphere. The Warrumbungles are famous for the darkness of its night skies, so when the sun goes down, settle back for an evening of stargazing.Take a virtual tour of Burbie Camp captured with Google Street View Trekker.

properties.name: Kings Plains Creek Campground
properties.description: With its superb location, Kings Plains Creek campground is a hit with adventurous, independent holidaymakers. The family will love spotting grey kangaroos, who tend to appear near the end of the day. Turquoise parrots and tiny diamond firetail finches are also often seen near the campground. As night falls, youll hear frogs singing and can even sit quietly on the banks and watch the microbats hunting above the water.Once youve settled in, strap on hiking boots for a walk along the creek to Kings Plains Falls, which only runs after rain. The trail is unmarked and there are areas where rock-hopping is necessary, but this is bushwalking at its best. It takes about 2.5 hours to get to the waterfall and back.Getting to the campground is easy from Glen Innes or Inverell, but you do need to carry gear along a walking track from the carpark.

properties.name: Lemon Tree Flat Campground
properties.description: Positioned on a large grassed area alongside Severn River, Lemon Tree Flat campground is a great place to base yourself while you uncover the remote attractions of Kwiambal National Park. There are plenty of tables and wood barbecues  pack a picnic for a leisurely lunch or bring a tent for a weekend getaway to truly appreciate the cypress pine woodlands and abundant wildlife. Within easy walking distance of the campground are fishing, swimming and hiking opportunities, along with plenty of chances to entertain a little birdwatching you might even spot a wedge-tailed eagle circling above your camping spot. If privacy is what you're after, bring some hiking boots and follow Junction walk, a four-kilometre trail from the campground which takes you to the junction of Severn and Macintyre rivers.
