Gulaga, the Mother Mountain

Return to the T-intersection at Wallaga Lake Road and turn right. Travel 800 metres and turn right into Lake View Drive at Wallaga Lake Heights. From the car park at the end of this road walk east along the lake's edge on the track to Murunna Point. The sign is 200 metres along this track at the small pavilion with carved posts.

### Yuin Umbarra, Djiringanj Lands, Wallaga Lake & Merriman Island

Return to Wallaga Lake Road, turn right and continue for 1.5 kilometres to the rest area on the right immediately before Wallaga Lake Bridge. The sign is in the car park area near the amenities block.

### Najenuga

From the rest area turn right and cross the Wallaga Lake single lane bridge. Continue on this road, Bermagui Road, for 2.6 kilometres. The last trail sign is on your left about 750 metres past Youngs Road.

_Sincere thanks also to Wallaga Lake-Bermagui Men's Shed for helping to install the signs, Mumbulla Foundation for partially funding this project and Bega Valley Shire Council for their support and encouragement._

properties.name: Riverglade Caravan Park
properties.description: Caravan park on the river edge

properties.name: Tumbarumba Caravan Park
properties.description: Lovely quiet and grassy caravan park with Tumbarumba creek crossing through. Unpowered/powered campsite available, as well as cabins and lodge rooms.

properties.name: The Woodlands Place
properties.description: A gently undulating paddock welcoming self sufficient campers. Fire pit onsite. Get back to basics surrounded by nature.

properties.name: Wooldridge Recreation and Fossicking Reserve
properties.description:
The Wooldridge Recreation & Fossicking Reserve is located approximately 6km from Uralla township along the Kingstown Road. It offers ample parking for caravans and campervans, free camping, toilet facilities, picnic tables, wood fired barbeques (subject to fire restrictions) and fresh drinking water.

Relax under the ghost gums on a hot summer’s day and be serenaded by the variety of bird life that calls the reserve home. Be sure to keep an eye out for the occasional kangaroo or wallaby passing through.

**Gold Pan Hire**
Gold pans can be hired from the Uralla Visitor Information Centre during opening hours.

Pan & Sieve Sets are available for hire at a rate of $19.60 per day + $50 deposit. Pick up and pay at the Uralla Visitor Information Centre, 104 Bridge Street, Uralla.

**Pets**
Pets are allowed into the reserve, but owners are requested to keep them on a leash at all times. Please use the rubbish bins provided to dispose of litter. Shooting is prohibited.

properties.name: Wollomombi Falls
properties.description: Wollomombi Falls is one of the highest waterfalls in Australia, with a single drop of 119 meters. It is located in the New England National Park in New South Wales. The waterfall is a popular tourist destination, and it is especially beautiful after heavy rain. The mist from the waterfall can sometimes shroud the views, but this only adds to the mystique of the place.

properties.name: Tucki Tucki Nature Reserve
properties.description:
Tucki Tucki Nature Reserve is a beautiful and unique nature reserve. It is home to a variety of native Australian wildlife, including koalas, platypus, and Richmond birdwing butterflies.
Tucki Tucki Nature Reserve is one of the best places in Australia to see koalas in the wild. There are a number of walking trails that wind through the reserve, and you're likely to spot koalas high up in the trees.
The reserve is home to a variety of native Australian plants and animals, including eucalyptus trees, kangaroos, and kookaburras.
There are a number of walking trails that wind through the reserve, ranging from easy to challenging.
The best time to visit the reserve is early in the morning or late in the afternoon, when the koalas are most active.

properties.name: The Lion of Waterloo
properties.description:
The Historic Lion of Waterloo is believed to be the oldest licensed hotel west of the Blue Mountains that is still standing. 
Dating back to 1841, The Lion of Waterloo was a popular destination for coaches, station hands, settlers and later miners. 
Cobb and Co coaches would regularly stop here to change horses and refresh passengers before continuing on their journey.

properties.name: The Great North Road Convict Trail
properties.description:
The Great North Road Convict Trail is a must-do for any tourist interested in Australian history. This historic road was built by convicts and completed in 1836. Up to 720 convicts - some in chains - worked on the road, which spanned 264 km, connecting Sydney to the settlements of the Hunter Valley. It features spectacular and beautifully preserved examples of stonework and a fascinating glimpse into the lives of these early settlers.
The trail winds its way through some of the most beautiful countryside in New South Wales, passing through lush forests, over rolling hills, and across sparkling rivers. Along the way, you'll see convict-built bridges, culverts, and retaining walls, as well as the ruins of old convict stockades and settlements.

properties.name: Sydney Harbour Circle Walk
properties.description: Sydney Harbour is one of the great harbours of the world. This 26 kilometre circle walk and over 45 kilometres of optional loops explores west of the Harbour Bridge to Hunters Hill. It is a truly magnificent walk focusing on the harbour itself, the expanse of water, the bridges, islands, urban bushland and city skyline.

properties.name: South Coast Harvest Experience Farm Gate Trail
properties.description: Enjoy sampling the best of South Coast produce. You can pick up fresh oysters and local seafood, indulge in chocolate treats, wander through olive groves, visit wineries; enjoy seasonal fruit and vegetables, either fresh from the grower, or hand crafted into delicious preserves. Chat with local farmers and find out how their fresh produce is grown.

properties.name: Snowy Valleys Way Touring Route
properties.description:
The Snowy Valleys Way is a breathtaking scenic route in southeastern Australia that spans through the picturesque Snowy Valleys region. 

This captivating journey takes you on a meandering path through lush valleys, charming towns, and serene landscapes. Along the way, you'll encounter diverse attractions, from pristine rivers and lakes to snow-capped mountains, making it a year-round destination. 

Sample exquisite local wines, savor gourmet cuisine, and explore cultural gems in welcoming communities. Outdoor enthusiasts can partake in activities like hiking, fishing, and skiing in the surrounding national parks. Whether you're seeking relaxation or adventure, the Snowy Valleys Way offers an unforgettable Australian experience with its natural beauty and warm hospitality.

properties.name: Self Drive Geology and Nature Trails
properties.description:
Discover ancient lava flows, wonderful wildflower displays and evidence of the rich geological history of the Warrumbungle Region on one of these rewarding self-drive nature trails. 
Gamble Creek Nature Tour, is a 70 kilometre return trip to Binnaway.

properties.name: Sea Acres Rainforest Centre
properties.description: Sea Acres Rainforest Centre, a coastal rainforest reserve in New South Wales, Australia, is a unique ecosystem where land and sea meet. Visitors can explore the rainforest's ancient trees, cascading waterfalls, and diverse wildlife, including platypus, koalas, and echidnas. Sea Acres also offers educational programs and tours, making it a great place to learn about the rainforest and its importance.

properties.name: RAAF Wagga Heritage Centre
properties.description: The Aviation Heritage Centre originally opened in 1995 as the 'RAAF Museum - Wagga Annex' to provide a focus on the Air Force's involvement in the Riverina and access to the history and memorabilia of military aviation and training. It closed in 2005 due to structural issues and reopened after repairs in October 2010 as the RAAF Wagga Heritage Centre (later renamed the RAAF Wagga Aviation Heritage Centre). The Centre is manned by volunteers from within the Wagga Wagga community and managed by RAAF Reservists.

properties.name: Protesters Falls
properties.description:
The walk to get to Protesters Falls is nothing short of spectacular, combine it with a jaw dropping waterfall and it's one of the best short walks in NSW. 

Located in World Heritage Nightcap National Park, Protesters Falls is a must see while exploring the Lismore Hinterland. The easy 700m walk from Terania Creek Picnic Area winds its way through the bangalow palm forest to the base of the falls.

Swimming is not permitted in the area as it is home to the endangered Fleay's barred frog.

properties.name: Narrabeen Lagoon
properties.description:
Narrabeen Lagoon is a place where you can go bushwalking, enjoy numerous water sports, or simply relax in one of Sydney's most spectacular environments. 
Narrabeen Lagoon is also one of the northern beaches greatest natural assets and is a haven for wildlife. 
Access to the northern beaches largest coastal lagoon has been greatly improved thanks to the Multi-use Trail around the entire lagoon, which can be used by walkers, cyclists and people of all abilities. 
The Narrabeen Lagoon trail is an easy 8.4km loop on a well formed, shared track without steps. Take a journey through beautiful ecosystems with an abundance of wildlife, cultural heritage and historical sites.

properties.name: Nadgee Wilderness Walk
properties.description: Nadgee wilderness walk is a spectacular 55km walk from Merrica River to Mallacoota, with coastal views. It's great for birdwatching, whale watching and camping.

properties.name: Muswellbrook Heritage Walk
properties.description:
Muswellbrook Heritage Walk is approximately 4.5 kilometres long and may be commenced from M.M. Hyndes Bailey and Co Surveyors, 208 Bridge Street, or the Railway Station, Market Street. 

You can start and stop at any point and pick up again at another time where you left off. Fine old buildings dating back to the mid-1800s, grand residences, community precincts - testimony to the good times and hard times; all of great importance to the development of Muswellbrook - roads, rail, bureaucracy, arts and culture, entertainment, business and community. 

A copy of the Muswellbrook Heritage Town Walk can be downloaded from the web or a copy can be obtained from Muswellbrook Visitor Information Centre. A map is available with each site shown on the map and numbered.

properties.name: Mount Mutton Walking Trail
properties.description:
Mount Mutton Walking Trail starts at the award-winning Alma Park, in Queen Street, Uralla. It crosses Thunderbolt's Way and ascends into bushland winding around Mount Mutton. 

There are glimpses of the town centre through the trees as you reach the higher ground and there is a diversion from the track to the top of Mount Mutton, for those wanting to view the town from the highest point. The track is well-marked on Mount Mutton and is quite wide. It leads back to Fitzroy Road north, and follows Thunderbolt's Way past the bowling club, crossing back to finish at Alma Park.

properties.name: Lightning Ridge Bore Baths
properties.description:
Lightning Ridge Bore Baths is a unique and popular tourist attraction in Lightning Ridge, New South Wales, Australia. It is a complex of five natural swimming pools that are filled with hot artesian water from the Great Artesian Basin.

The bore baths range in temperature from 36 to 41 degrees Celsius, making them the perfect place to relax and soak in the natural minerals that are said to have therapeutic properties. The bore baths are also surrounded by lush gardens and picnic areas, making them a great place to spend a day with family and friends.

properties.name: Great Inland Way
properties.description: The Great Inland Way is the ultimate Aussie road trip. This 3000km fully-sealed route offers easy driving distances between a variety of charming towns and bustling regional centres, each with their own character and a range of visitor services and unique attractions. Experience a changing landscape as you weave your way through the quintessential Aussie bushland of the southern States to the wide-open spaces of the Outback and up to the tropical heart of Queensland - where the rainforest meets the reef.

properties.name: Fossil Rock
properties.description: An amazing fossil leaf deposit with particularly fine detail has been preserved in Dalton, located just 10 minutes north of Gunning. This 40 million year old fossil can be seen under the shelter in the park along Oolong Creek.

properties.name: Ferntree Gully Reserve
properties.description: Ferntree Gully is a highly scenic rainforest area 17 kilometres north of Rylstone. There are many walking tracks at Ferntree Gully that take you down into the cool narrow fern-tree studded valley floor, and/or around the top edge of the rocks where you can get an overview of the valley and the unusual rock formation.

properties.name: Depot Glen Pooles Grave and Sturts Cairn
properties.description: The sites of Depot Glen, Poole's Grave and a cairn were all established and built by the men of the 1845 Sturt Expedition. They are located on a privately owned sheep station, Mount Poole, and are accessible from Hawker Gate Road and Milparinka township.

properties.name: Coxs Road Interpretive Trail
properties.description:
Commissioned to build a road across the Blue Mountains, magistrate Lt. William Cox, with 30 convicts, started on 18 July 1814 at Emu Ford, completing the road to Bathurst on 14 January 1815 - a staggering 101.5 miles through the rugged mountainous country in just six months. 

Today you can trace the path of the original Coxs Road which varies little from the current alignment of the Great Western Highway. Explore the interpretive trail at key sites where you can discover stories of the road construction through notes from Cox's journal, learn of Aboriginal heritage and find paintings and drawings on this remarkable journey.

A Blue Mountains City Council, Blue Mountains Branch of National Trust Bicentenary project. Key sites are located at: Glenbrook Park, Glenbrook; Manners Park, Springwood; Bulls Camp Reserve, Woodford; Coronation Park, Wentworth Falls; Blackheath Cemetery entry; Blackheath and Mount York.

properties.name: Coomee Nulunga Cultural Trail
properties.description: The Coomee Nulunga Cultural Trail travels through low windswept heath, capturing a living sculpture by the moods and breezes of the Pacific Ocean. The sculpture of Corroboree Man, Bulan Yuin welcomes all to the trail. Throughout the trail, many Garawanda Daran (Dreaming Poles) have been positioned and makes its way towards the beach, winding through the last contours in the way of the Rainbow Serpent, the creator in Aboriginal Dreamtime stories.

properties.name: Clarence Gorge
properties.description:
Visit Kangaroo Island in a day on this tour from Adelaide with all the top sights, a 2 course lunch, Kangaroo Island ferry tickets and return included. Kangaroo Island tours are the best way to experience the scenery with a local and there are plenty of opportunities to taste the yummy samples and see wildlife along the way. 

**Highlights** 

- Return coach/ferry to Kangaroo Island from Adelaide 
- Delicious 2-course lunch at Emu Ridge Eucalyptus Distillery 
- Free Flight Birds of Prey Presentation 
- Spectacular views of Pennington Bay 
- Structured wine tasting at False Cape Wines 
- Clifford's Honey Farm Shop visit

properties.name: Captains Walk
properties.description:
Unique to Cootamundra, the Captains Walk features 42 bronze sculptures of Australian Test Cricket Captains, along with Unaarrimim the leading Aboriginal player in the first Australian cricket team to tour England in 1868. 

Cootamundra has strong connections with two Australian test cricket captains, being the birthplace of Sir Donald Bradman and a former home of Bill Murdoch.

properties.name: Capertee Valley Bird Trail
properties.description: The Capertee Valley Bird Trail has 19 easily accessible bird watching sites each marked by a numbered roadside sign. The bird trail lies within the traditional country of the Wiradjuri people. Located on the western edge of the Blue Mountains near Capertee, and only three hours travel from Sydney

properties.name: Bogey Hole
properties.description:
Take a dip in the Bogey Hole, a stunning ocean pool hand-carved by convict labor in 1819. Marvel at the convicts' amazing achievement as you swim in the pool while the waves crash against the rocks.

The Bogey Hole was constructed by order of Commandant James Morisset in about 1820 for his own personal use. Morisset was Commandant of Newcastle, New South Wales, from 1818 to 1823. He was a strict but fair leader, and he is credited with many improvements to the colony, including the construction of roads, bridges, and public buildings.

properties.name: Blue Mountains Botanic Garden Mount Tomah
properties.description:
The Blue Mountains Botanic Garden, Mount Tomah is the spectacular cool climate garden of the Royal Botanic Garden and Domain Trust. 

Located in the Blue Mountains, just 90 minutes from Sydney, the garden features thousands of plants from the southern hemisphere and around the world.

properties.name: Bens Walk
properties.description:
Bens Walk begins at the Nowra Showground. Enjoy superb elevated views of the river and mountains from Hanging Rock. 
The complete track provides a leisurely return walk of about 5.5 kilometres taking around two hours. A short return walk from the footbridge to the Showground and Hanging Rock takes around 10 minutes.

properties.name: Barmedman Mineral Pool
properties.description:
The Barmedman Mineral Pool is a natural pool located in the small town of Barmedman, New South Wales, Australia. The pool is fed by a mineral-rich spring, and the water is said to have therapeutic properties. The pool is open to the public and is a popular spot for swimming, soaking, and picnicking.

The Barmedman Mineral Pool is about 30 meters long and 10 meters wide. The water temperature is around 30 degrees Celsius, making it a refreshing place to swim on a hot day. The pool is surrounded by lush vegetation and sandstone cliffs, creating a beautiful and relaxing setting.

properties.name: Bare Island Fort Botany Bay
properties.description:
In 1885 concerned British members of society thought an invasion by Russia was imminent. To ease their fears, they built Bare Island Fort to protect Botany Bay (then known as 'Sydney's back door'). 
Since then, Bare Island Fort in Kamay Botany Bay National Park has developed a fascinating history. It's been an object of military pride. It's also been a place of shocking scandals and hidden secrets.

properties.name: Balancing Rock
properties.description: Balancing Rock is a unique and fascinating rock formation located in the Glen Innes District of New South Wales, Australia. It is a gigantic boulder of granite that rests precariously on a 300 millimeter point amongst other rock formations. Balancing Rock is on private property, but it can be viewed from the rest area which is marked with a Balancing Rock sign. The rest area is located 12 kilometres south of Glen Innes on the New England Highway.

properties.name: Angourie Blue Pool
properties.description:
The Angourie Blue Pool is extremely deep and is a very popular swimming hole. 

There is a walking track to the Angourie Blue Pool from the car park area at the eastern end of The Crescent, Angourie.

properties.name: Wake Up Sydney
properties.description: WakeUp! Sydney Central represents all that Sydney has to offer. It's fresh, its modern and the hub of backpacker activity - right in the heart of Sydney. WakeUp is the backpacker place to be! WakeUp! Is located opposite Central Station -and is also the first shuttle bus stop from the airport.

properties.name: The Entrance Backpackers
properties.description: At The Entrance Backpackers, you'll find the ambience relaxing and the surroundings irresistible. With only four dorm rooms they are a simple, boutique, friendly hostel. Great atmosphere and fun-loving staff will make you feel instantly at home.

properties.name: Six Foot Track Lodge
properties.description: The Six Foot Track Lodge is an architect-designed two cabin, 28-bed lodge on the heritage-listed Six Foot Track. The two cabins are joined by a large landing and are surrounded by the Cox's River, pleasant woodland and abundant bird life.

properties.name: Seventh Day Adventist Youth Centre
properties.description:
Seventh Day Adventist Youth Centre is an ideal location for group camps or family holidays.



Two dormitories accommodate up to 50 people in each block.  Eight cabins for up to 10 people in each one. The cabins can be self catered or fully catered with a commercial kitchen and dining hall.

properties.name: Regatta Point Holiday Park
properties.description:
Regatta Point Holiday Park – where tranquility finds you and sunsets and serenity are absolutely free.  Set on over 5 hectares in a natural setting on the shores of beautiful Wallaga Lake, Regatta Point Holiday Park offers visitors a feeling of peace and tranquility amongst gums and casuarinas, magical water and mountain views, and abundant water and forest bird life.

Invest in some down time or be as active as you like. Adjacent coastal wilderness, national parks, state forests and marine park make Regatta Point ideal as a base for well being, creativity, culture, canoeing and a host of other natural or adventure experiences.  A stay at Regatta Point will leave you enthralled with a timeless portrait of nature and tranquility.

properties.name: Kinchega Shearers Quarters
properties.description: Kinchega Shearers Quarters is approximately 111 kilometres south east of Broken Hill, located in Kinchega National Park. The Kinchega Shearer's Quarters provide an excellent opportunity to spend a night in the park without having to pitch a tent!

properties.name: Jolly Swagman Backpackers Sydney Hostel
properties.description: For over 20 years the Jolly Swagman Backpackers Sydney Hostel has been the heart and soul of the Australian Backpacker world. The Jolly Swagman Kings Cross Backpackers is owner operated accommodation and provides personalised service to all guests.

properties.name: Woolgoolga Lakeside Caravan Park
properties.description: $41.00 stay 7 pay 6

properties.name: Warragamba Reserve Camp
properties.description: Free campsite for campers, campervans. No tents. Need a code to the gate after hours, maximum stay for 48hrs. Toilets do lock down after 19:00.

properties.name: Boambee Beach
properties.description: Boambee Beach extends from Corambirra Point (near the Deep Sea Fishing Club) to Boambee Creek (north of Sawtell). The beach is not patrolled though popular with fishermen, horse trainers, joggers, jet-ski riders, four wheel drive enthusiasts, and dogs are allowed on the beach off the leash.

properties.name: NRMA Blue Dolphin Yamba Holiday Resort
properties.description:
NRMA Blue Dolphin Yamba Holiday Resort, formerly Blue Dolphin Holiday Resort, offers a feast of family fun and adventure on the sunny Far North Coast of NSW. You'll find us on absolute riverfront, just a stone’s throw from pristine surf beaches, fishing spots and spectacular kayaking trips.

Every day brings an incredible new experience. One day, you’ll be meeting dolphins or exploring nearby islands. The next, you’ll be racing down our stunning waterslides or sipping cocktails in our swim-up pool bar.

Whether you stay in a villa with water views or a pet friendly campsite, make the most of our fabulous facilities, from our kids’ waterpark and safari-themed mini-golf to our private jetty and boat ramp. We can’t wait to welcome you!

properties.name: Wellington Riverside Caravan Park
properties.description: Very nice park. Caravan sites look over the river.

properties.name: Rustic Caravan Park
properties.description:
Rustic Caravan Park is a little gem of a park spotted by What’s Up Downunder at Large reporter Allan Goldby. Here, city pressures quickly dissipate at this charming bush campground equipped with a few camping comforts for a pleasant stay.

Ideal for outdoor lovers! Here you’ll find a quiet and peaceful vide! Surrounded by nature. There is a leak near by where you can fish, kiak, paddle. Short distance from Bendalong Beach! No eletricity only a bethroom with cold/hot water. Ideal for scaping the busy and noise city life!  

990 Bendalong Road, Bendalong

properties.name: Bodalla Dairy Shed
properties.description: A very unique place where you can feed the animals and enjoy great food and in-house produced icecream. Accommodation also available.

properties.name: Canowindra Showgrounds
properties.description: Care taker will pickup cash in the afternoon/evening

properties.name: Comboyne Showground
properties.description:
$10 per adult per night, children under 16 free. Hot showers and limited powered sites.

Nestled in a picturesque grassy setting, Comboyne Showground offers a peaceful camping experience with basic facilities. On arrival, you may find yourself the only camper, as there’s no on-site manager or clear signage. Campers typically set up on the lower grassy area.

Unpowered sites are available at $10 per person per night, payable at the Community Centre in town the following day. The campground is a short walk from the charming town of Comboyne, where you’ll discover a great café serving an impressive lunch menu and excellent coffee. It's well worth a visit to this lovely town.

properties.name: Rolland Plains Recreation Reserve
properties.description: $15 unpowered for 2 people. $20 powered for 2. $5 extra for each extra person after 2. Phone ahead to book in. Hot showers, phone service, fires allowed, shelter with tables and lighting for night time.

properties.name: Gundy recreational ground
properties.description:
Contact Ian he will get back to you. 

Great relaxing little place. Fantastic local pub. General store. 

Head to the pickled goose for a coffee or feed 30ks up the road or have a coldie at the linga longer.

properties.name: Hare Krishna Village
properties.description: Hare Krishna Village is a large property located 45 minutes north of Byron Bay. Accommodation cost includes 3x vegetarian meals a day, 2x daily yoga classes, and other spiritual classes throughout the week (all optional). Hare Krishna Village is a bustling village full of travellers, yogis, and spiritual people from all walks of life-everyone is welcome. Minimum stay 3 nights.

properties.name: Premer Hotel
properties.description: A cruise or ride to Premer puts you at one of the friendliest pubs on the plains, forget the 9-5 grind over a hearty meal, refreshing drink & sleepover too

properties.name: Fernlee River Camping
properties.description: River Camping

properties.name: Ellenborough Reserve
properties.description:
A beautiful free camping spot with plenty of camping space for all kinds of camping. 

The river is astounding and deep with rocks to jump from.

properties.name: Bateau Beach Cafe
properties.description: Best Coffee on the Coast and be sure to try their Bacon & Egg Rolls. Eat in or takeaway and walk over to the beach

properties.name: River Retreat Caravan Park
properties.description:
River Retreat Caravan Park is a quiet, dog friendly park on Powered Tourist Sites. With our newer Studio Cabins,
Dog Friendly Cabins and our Riverview Retreat for couples and families we are a perfect quiet getaway and
located only three minute’s drive to the start of Gold Coast Beaches.

properties.name: Narromine Rockwall Tourist Park
properties.description: Narromine Rockwall Tourist Park is a family-friendly, relaxed stopover for you and the kids, or a base from which to explore nearby areas including Dubbo and surrounding regions.

properties.name: Dalli's Campground
properties.description: Family campground located in the Capertee Valley, hot showers and flushing toilets, firewood supplied, pizza oven, Pet Friendly, next to Coco Creek.

properties.name: Sunvalley Nudist Retreat
properties.description:
Sunvalley is a nudist retreat for those willing to try the nudist lifestyle. Sunvalley offers unpowered, riverside camping on private property, in a tranquil and peaceful setting, but still close to Sydney 

This is private land gate locked at 6pm. 

If you don't want to try the nudist lifestyle don't come.

Bookings required.

properties.name: Barlow Showground
properties.description: Free camping site, no toilets or showers. Must be self sufficient. Rubbish bins provided.

properties.name: The Gorge Campground
properties.description:
If you are just up for a day trip or looking to settle in for a few nights, our fresh mountain air & wide open space offers everyone something. From your avid canoeist or fisherman to the more relaxed bird watcher or book worm. You will not be let down.
​
The Clarence Gorge, and your hosts Buck and Belinda offer you,
​
Catch and Release fishing
​
Bush walking and exploring
​
Great river for boating and canoeing (bring your own equipment)
​
Amazing scenery, waterfalls, wild life and a huge variety of birds
​
Camping or accommodation
​
Pet friendly campsites
​
Relaxed country hospitality.                         -                                                                                              https://m. Youtube. Com/watch?v=H1i2OY3dPeM

properties.name: Free Campground the River
properties.description: Free Campground at the River. You have to drive left Side after the Bridge! Very good Spot for Overnight.

properties.name: How's the Serenity Camping Ground
properties.description:
The Camping Ground is run on and in conjunction with our Working Cattle Property of nearly 800Ha (2000 ac)
Open Spaces and shade,  we have plenty of it, so spread 
out and enjoy the peace and quiet . "How's the Serenity"

Feel Safe and Secure while camped overnight or use us as a base and stay longer to visit the local attractions.

properties.name: Starview Primitive Campsite
properties.description:
Camp ground opened in 2017, 15 unpowered campsites with hot showers, and BBQ areas. 

Beautiful surroundings. 

Phone, email or visit Information Centre in Broken Hill to book.
properties.fees: $10 pp, and $6 entry fee into the park.

properties.name: Waa Gorge Walking Track
properties.description:
Waa Gorge walking track in New South Wales, Australia, offers a captivating nature experience. 

This short but scenic trail winds through lush eucalyptus forests, leading you to the stunning Waa Gorge lookout. In less than an hour, you'll witness breathtaking views of the gorge's rugged sandstone walls and the meandering Capertee River below. Keep an eye out for native wildlife and vibrant birdlife along the way. 

It's a perfect spot for a quick nature escape and a great photo opportunity. Remember to bring water, wear comfortable hiking shoes, and be mindful of the natural surroundings.

properties.name: Thegoa Lagoon & Reserve
properties.description: Basic river-side camping area, no amenities so suitable for self-contained vehicles only.

properties.name: Pat Morton Lookout
properties.description: Pat Morton Lookout is a popular tourist destination in Lennox Head, New South Wales, Australia. It is located on the top of Lennox Point, and offers stunning views of the Pacific Ocean, Seven Mile Beach, and the surrounding coastline.

properties.name: Urunga Boardwalk
properties.description:
The Urunga Boardwalk is a 150-metre long boardwalk located in Urunga, New South Wales, Australia. It is a popular spot for bird watching, fishing, and walking.

The boardwalk starts at the Urunga Wharf and winds its way through a mangrove forest. It offers stunning views of the Kalang River and the Pacific Ocean.

The boardwalk is wheelchair accessible and it is open all year round. There is a small car park located near the wharf.

properties.name: Maca's Camping Ground
properties.description: Maca’s Camping Ground is located close to Mt. Jerusalem National Park, just off the Main Arm Road, northwest of Mullumbimby. Maca’s Camping Ground overlooks the stunning Mount Jerusalum National Park and beatutiful Northern NSW countryside. Being short drive from Brunswick Heads off Australia’s world famous, Pacific Highway, Macas is a well located place to stop off and visit while on your East Coast Road Trip.

properties.name: Stuart Town Recreation Reserve
properties.description: Trust run ground, showers and toilets, plenty of space for all vehicles. Donations box on site.

properties.name: Thunderbolt's Hideout
properties.description:
Thunderbolts Hideout, located in New South Wales, Australia, is a captivating natural wonder hidden within the rugged landscapes of the Barrington Tops region. 

This enchanting hideaway offers visitors a glimpse into the infamous bushranger Frederick Ward, also known as Captain Thunderbolt's, hidden world during the 19th century. Nestled amidst lush rainforests, the hideout is a serene haven showcasing pristine waterfalls, serene creeks, and ancient eucalyptus trees. 

Explore the area's rich history and stunning scenery through walking trails, wildlife spotting, and immersive storytelling about Thunderbolt's exploits.

properties.name: Grand Canyon Walking Track
properties.description: The Grand Canyon Walking Track is a 6.3-kilometre loop track that takes in the spectacular scenery of the Grose Valley of the Blue Mountains. The track offers stunning views of the canyon, waterfalls, and rainforest.

properties.name: Watagan Headquarters Camping Area
properties.description: During the 1940s, Watagan Headquarters was the site of a camp for workers constructing forest roads. It was later used as a camp barracks for maintenance crews who were trucked into the forest on Monday morning and out again on Saturday morning. The headquarters is on the route of the Great North Walk, a 250 kilometre walking track from Sydney to Newcastle. The camping area is open and grassed, surrounded by native forest and blue leaved stringybark plantations. No water or toilets.

properties.name: Sublime Point Lookout
properties.description:
Experience the sensation of standing on the very edge of the world at Sublime Point lookout in Leura. This enchanting spot, perched high above the Blue Mountains National Park, treats visitors to endless vistas that seem to stretch into eternity. It's a cherished destination for both nature enthusiasts and those seeking a serene picnic spot. 

Sublime Point lookout is not just a feast for the eyes; it's also a playground for the adventurous souls who find joy in rock climbing. Accessible via an uncomplicated trail, keep your eyes peeled during summer for gang-gangs and cockatoos amidst the casuarina trees. As you traverse a bridge spanning a breathtaking ravine, you'll soon reach the lookout platform. 

Here, lose yourself in the panoramic views of the picturesque Jamison Valley, where the untamed wilderness unfolds endlessly before you. From this vantage point, you'll gain a fresh perspective on Katoomba and the sprawling majesty of The Three Sisters. On misty mornings, witness the awe-inspiring sight of Mount Solitary emerging from the shrouds of clouds, a truly magnificent spectacle.

properties.name: Victoria Falls Walking Track
properties.description:
Almost immediately upon embarking on your hike, you'll encounter the Victoria Falls lookout. 

Pause here to inhale the crisp mountain air and behold the breathtaking vistas spanning the sandstone escarpment and the vast Grose Wilderness. Keep your ears attuned for the distinct calls of sulphur-crested and yellow-tailed black cockatoos.

Although it may be difficult to tear yourself away, to witness the waterfall, follow the path to the left of the lookout. The steep trail meanders down the sandstone cliff in a series of zigzags. Along the way, you'll find short detours leading to the charming Victoria Creek Cascades and the summit of Victoria Falls, while the primary trail continues its descent to the base of the waterfall.

Consider bringing along a picnic lunch to savor amidst the stunning waterfall surroundings, where the waters tumble approximately 20 meters over a rocky overhang. In the summertime, this location offers a tranquil oasis, ideal for relaxation in the shade of the luxuriant canopy.

The arduous journey back up to the carpark typically requires approximately 60 to 90 minutes.

properties.name: Jamison Lookout
properties.description:
amison Lookout in the Blue Mountains offers breathtaking vistas of the iconic Three Sisters rock formation and the lush Jamison Valley below. 

Located in New South Wales, Australia, this popular viewpoint provides a glimpse into the region's stunning natural beauty, with rugged cliffs and eucalyptus-covered hillsides. Visitors can enjoy hiking trails, picnicking, and photography opportunities while soaking in the panoramic scenery. 

It's a must-visit spot for anyone exploring the Blue Mountains, known for its awe-inspiring landscapes and rich Aboriginal heritage.

properties.name: Mungo Camping
properties.description:
Mungo Brush campground is a popular place near Hawks Nest on the north coast. Featuring caravan sites, it’s near the beach and the lake; you can go fishing, walking and kayaking.

Camping type: 	Tent, Camper trailer site, Caravan site, Camping beside my vehicle


Facilities	Picnic tables, barbecue facilities, boat ramp, toilets


What to bring	Drinking water, cooking water


Price	
Rates and availability are displayed when making an online booking
A minimum nightly rate applies, which includes the first 2 occupants
Peak season: NSW school holidays, long weekends, 1st December to 31st January
Off-peak season: all other times
Peak nightly rate: $24 per night (includes 2 people). Additional adult (16+years) $12 per night, additional child (5–15years) $6 per night, infants (0–4 years) free.
Off-peak nightly rate: $17 per night (includes 2 people). Additional adult (16+years) $8.50 per night, additional child (5–15years) $4 per night, infants (0–4years) free.


Entry fees	
Park entry fees are not included in your camping fees.

Bookings:  Bookings are required. Book online or call the National Parks Contact Centre on 1300 072 757.
Please note	
Check-in after 12pm. Check out by 11 am.
There is a maximum of 2 campsites per customer name. To book for a larger education group, please email the Pacific Palms Booti Booti office
A licenced café, telephone and very basic supplies are available about 5km away, across the ferry crossing.

properties.name: Kookaburra Camping And Caravan Park
properties.description: Bushwalking, birdwatching, large BBQ hut, clean modern bathroom. Beautiful views, camp among the gums, plenty of room to manoeuvre large vehicles, wildlife, pet friendly, fire pits with wood, disabled access

properties.name: Bellingen Showground
properties.description: Typical Showgrounds with power and water facilities. Pretty quiet, located close to town. The care taker who lives on site is very friendly.
properties.fees: $18 per person with power, $25 for two ppl, $15 non power

properties.name: Tambar Springs Showground
properties.description:
This is a Free Camping area provided by the Hotel for patrons for overnight stays.

No Tents

1 night max

properties.name: Windsor Heritage Walk
properties.description: Windsor is one of the oldest European settlements in Australia. The historic charm of Windsor can be explored on self-guided heritage walks. You can explore the beautiful town famous for its many heritage buildings with some being designed by the convict architect Sir Francis Greenway (St Matthews Anglican Church and The Windsor Courthouse). You can pick up your free Heritage Highlights booklet from either the Hawkesbury Regional Museum in Baker Street Windsor or from the Hawkesbury Visitor Information Centre.

properties.name: Wentworth Falls Lookout
properties.description:
Within Blue Mountains National Park, five minutes from the highway, is one of the most majestic waterfalls on the plateau. 

Wentworth Falls picnic area is a great base to explore the lush world of rainforests and waterfalls along a range of spectacular walking tracks to suit all the family.

properties.name: Wee Jasper Reserves
properties.description:
Wee Jasper Reserves are a popular holiday, recreation and touring destination, with beautiful camping areas beside rushing rivers and cascading streams, idyllic picnic spots and pristine bush. 

The Wee Jasper Valley offers all sorts of outdoor and underground activities.

properties.name: Uralla Heritage Walk
properties.description:
The Uralla Heritage Walk is a self guided walking tour which showcases over fifty heritage buildings and historical features within the township. 

Highlights of the walk include McCrossin's Mill, a three storey brick and granite flour mill built in 1870, which now houses a multi-award winning museum; and the Heart Stone, a heart-shaped basalt rock embedded in a retaining wall as a memorial to the stonemason's beloved.

properties.name: The Bucketts Way
properties.description: The Bucketts Way is a 151-kilometre (94 mi) rural road that links Gloucester to Taree and Raymond Terrace, in New South Wales, Australia. It is a former alignment of the Pacific Highway, and was later named after the Bucketts Mountains, a prominent mountain range near Gloucester. The entire route is designated as Tourist Route 2.

properties.name: Top 40 Orchard
properties.description: Established since 1948 this is a family owned and operated business which sells direct to the public via their roadside stall seven days a week. Top 40 Orchard also sell their produce at local markets in Picton and Camden.

properties.name: The Rock Nature Reserve
properties.description: The Rock Nature Reserve - Kengal Aboriginal Place offers scenic picnic spots, walking opportunities, picnicking, birdwatching and rock climbing, close to Wagga Wagga.

properties.name: The Living Desert and Sculptures
properties.description: Within the Living Desert Reserve are two must see major attractions - the sculptures and the flora and fauna sanctuary. The Sculptures comprise 12 sandstone artworks which highlight the skyline, all with a story to tell.

properties.name: Hampden Bridge Kangaroo Valley
properties.description:
Hampden Bridge is a wonderful attraction in Kangaroo Valley, just 2.5 hours from Sydney or Canberra between the South Coast and Southern Highlands. The bridge is Australia's last surviving wooden suspension bridge and has a special design with gothic Victorian sandstone towers that make it look like the entrance to a secret medieval castle.

Take a self-guided tour of the bridge and learn its story. If you have a smart phone, watch the film about Hampden Bridge and the community and RMS's action to help restore it. Watch it while here and discover why Kangaroo Valley is Australia's most beautiful Valley.

Things to do at Hampden Bridge include visit the Pioneer Museum, enjoy a barbecue in the museum's park, walk in the park or down the footpath, relax and enjoy the Hampden Bridge Park with lawn and cafe, or launch your canoe in the river.

properties.name: Terramungamine Rock Grooves
properties.description:
Be amazed by the 150 rock carvings created by the Tubbagah people at the Terramungamine Rock Grooves. The site of ancient rocks is of historical significance and is located along the Macquarie River. 

It was used by the Wiradjuri Tribe to shape tools and spears and was an important meeting place for the Tubbagah people.

properties.name: Taronga Western Plains Zoo
properties.description:
Get up close and personal with both native and exotic animals at the expansive Taronga Western Plains Zoo in Dubbo, located in the scenic countryside of New South Wales. With over 500 animals hailing from five different continents, this is a wildlife lover's paradise. 

If you're in the mood for a true safari experience, you can opt to stay within the zoo itself, either at a campsite or in a self-contained cabin or catered lodge. 

Explore the zoo at your own pace by hopping on small carts or renting bicycles, pausing along the way to admire the captivating wildlife. Daily talks and unforgettable animal encounters await, featuring fascinating creatures such as black rhinos, meerkats, giraffes, elephants, zebras, lions, and ring-tailed lemurs.

properties.name: Sydney Harbour Bridge Pylon Lookout
properties.description:
Soaring high above the iconic Sydney Harbour Bridge, the Sydney Harbour Bridge Pylon Lookout offers visitors breathtaking 360-degree views of Sydney and its surrounds.

Accessible by elevator and stairs, the lookout is located inside the southern pylon of the bridge and provides unparalleled panoramic vistas of the city skyline, the Opera House, the harbor, and the Blue Mountains.

properties.name: Spring Creek Wetlands Walk
properties.description: Located only a few minutes west of the Kiama Post Office, you will discover a wonderful example of rehabilitated wetlands. To get there follow Terralong Street towards Jamberoo, turn right into Dido Street, then Glenbrook Drive. The entrance to the park is from a small car park.

properties.name: Solitary Islands Aquarium
properties.description:
The Solitary Islands Aquarium is a public aquarium located at Southern Cross University's National Marine Science Centre in Coffs Harbour, New South Wales, Australia. It is named after the nearby Solitary Islands Marine Park. The aquarium was opened in 2000 and is home to over 1,000 marine animals from the coastal and oceanic waters of the Coffs Coast region. 

The aquarium is divided into a number of different sections, each of which focuses on a different aspect of the marine environment

properties.name: Silverton Heritage Walking Trail
properties.description: Take a scenic walk on Silverton's Heritage Walking Trail. It takes around two hours walking time, taking in all of Silverton's sights and historic buildings. During the walk you will go through a railroad cutting and also take in the fantastic Mundi Mundi Plains.

properties.name: Sea Cliff Bridge
properties.description:
The Sea Cliff Bridge is a cantilevered concrete road bridge that carries the Lawrence Hargrave Drive over Coalcliff Beach in the Illawarra region of New South Wales, Australia. 

It is 665 metres long and 50.6 metres high at its highest point. 

The bridge was opened in 2005 and is a popular tourist destination, offering stunning views of the Pacific Ocean and the surrounding coastline.

properties.name: Sassafras Nuts
properties.description: Sassafras Nuts is a commercial chestnut and walnut farm located at Sassafras in the Budawang Ranges. The farm was established in the early 1980s and has over 1000 chestnut trees and several hundred walnut trees. They welcome visitors and groups to the farm during the autumn harvest.

properties.name: Rotary Walk
properties.description: Rotary Walk (Djirringanj Peoples Walk): A 2.4km clifftop walk from Spencer Park to Bar Beach, offering stunning views of Merimbula Lake and plenty of wildlife. End your walk at a popular surf beach or watch the boats head out to sea.

properties.name: Rocky Creek Dam
properties.description: Patient nature lovers may spot a platypus at Rocky Creek Dam. The dam wall is 27 metres high, 187 metres above sea level and, when full, the dam holds 14,000 mega litres of water. The dam has a platypus viewing platform, elevated boardwalk and pontoon bridge. There are picnic and barbecue facilities with wood supplied, benches, tables and children's play equipment. Four walks are available, ranging from 1.2 kilometres (20 minutes) to six kilometres (two hours) in length. Water Dragon Walk takes you up the hill to the lookout.

properties.name: Razorback Lookout Evans Head
properties.description:
Approximately 45 metres above sea level, Razorback Lookout overlooks the NSW North Coastline and Evans Head Township. 

The lookout is wheel chair accessible and is fitted with excellent barbecue and picnic facilities, public toilet facilities and ample parking spaces making it the perfect spot to enjoy the picturesque scenery of our beautiful region.

properties.name: Point Danger Lookout
properties.description:
Point Danger Lookout is a popular tourist destination on the Gold Coast in Queensland. It is located on a headland between Coolangatta and Tweed Heads, and offers stunning views of the Pacific Ocean, coastline, and hinterland. The lookout is named after the dangerous coral reefs that lie offshore, which have claimed many ships over the years. Captain James Cook named the headland Point Danger on his voyage to Australia in 1770. 

Today, Point Danger Lookout is a safe and popular place to visit. Visitors can enjoy the views from the lookout platform, or take a walk along the Centaur Remembrance Walk, which commemorates the loss of the Australian Hospital Ship Centaur in 1943. 

The lookout is also home to a number of other attractions, including the Captain Cook Memorial, the Point Danger Lighthouse, and the Point Danger Cafe.

properties.name: Pilliga Artesian Bore Baths
properties.description: The natural health-giving waters that flow into the Pilliga Artesian Bore Baths have been doing so for well over a century. This facility is found just East of the village of Pilliga along the Pilliga Road (approximately 56 kilometres from Wee Waa/sealed road).

properties.name: Pierces Pass Lookout
properties.description:
Pierces Pass Lookout is a popular spot for hiking and walking in the Blue Mountains National Park in New South Wales, Australia. It offers stunning views of the Grose River Valley and the surrounding mountains. There are a number of different walks that you can do from the lookout, ranging from easy to challenging.

The easiest walk is the short walk to the lookout itself. This walk is suitable for all ages and fitness levels, and it takes around 15 minutes to complete.

properties.name: Old Saint Lukes Studio
properties.description:
Old Saint Lukes Studio is situated in an historic stone building constructed in 1848 as a church and school. The gallery is home to the wood-fired ceramics of Ian Jones and Moraig McKenna. 

Ian and Moraig's works are fired in a 9 metre long anagama style wood-fired kiln.

properties.name: Mount Gulaga Walk
properties.description:
Gulaga, an ancient volcano cloaked in lush forests, holds immense cultural significance for the Aboriginal people, particularly the Yuin women of the South Coast of New South Wales. This historical site, steeped in tradition, also bears the mark of the 1894 gold rush, with a rugged trail constructed for eager miners. Begin your journey by taking the gravel path that meanders between the cafe and car park in Tilba Tilba, embarking on an unforgettable adventure. 

As you make your way, pause at 'Halfway Rock,' where the Battery Trail diverges from the main path, leading you 1.6 kilometres along the ridge to the remnants of the mine manager's dwelling. After exploring this historical site, rejoin the main trail, and approximately 30 minutes later, you'll arrive at 'The Saddle.' This tranquil resting spot unveils the splendor of enormous granite tors concealed within the rainforest. From here, muster your strength for the final ascent to the summit, which offers breathtaking panoramic views of the coastal landscape. 

This scenic hike spans 14 kilometres round-trip and is estimated to take around five hours to complete. It is rated as a challenging trek, commencing near the cafe in Tilba Tilba.

properties.name: Mount Gladstone Lookout
properties.description: The Mount Gladstone Lookout and Nature Reserve sits in 125 hectares of native bushland less than four kilometres from the edge of Cooma township, offering magnificent views across the Monaro Plains and to the peaks of the Snowy Mountains from the two easily accessible viewing platforms.

properties.name: Mount Blackheath Lookout
properties.description:
Travel along Shipley Plateau through a mix of bush (spot the waratahs in Spring), small farms and orchards. 

At the end you will reach Mount Blackheath Lookout with views to the north and west to the Great Dividing Range over the Kanimbla Valley.

properties.name: Mogo Bushwalk
properties.description:
Mogo Bushwalk offers an enchanting escape into the heart of nature within Mogo State Forest, New South Wales, Australia. This serene trail spans approximately 4 kilometres (2.5 miles) and treats visitors to an immersive Australian wilderness experience. 

As you meander through the lush eucalyptus forest, expect to encounter native flora and fauna, including colorful birdlife and wallabies. The well-maintained track features interpretive signs, enhancing your understanding of the local ecosystem. 

The highlight is undoubtedly the picturesque waterfall, which provides a tranquil spot to pause and appreciate the beauty of this pristine environment.

properties.name: Mitchell Ridge Lookout
properties.description:
Mitchell Ridge Lookout is an historic lookout and rest area, named after Sir Thomas Mitchell who supervised the building of the Pass by convict labour in 1832. An obelisk at the lookout commemorates the opening of Victoria Pass in 1832. 

The Pass is one of the oldest and most significant engineered works in Australia.

properties.name: Merimbula Boardwalk
properties.description: Merimbula Boardwalk: A scenic 3.4km boardwalk meanders through mangrove forests, past oyster farms, and offers stunning sunset views. Look for Merimbula's resident seal and grab a coffee at Sunny's Kiosk. Foot traffic only.

properties.name: Mallanganee Lookout
properties.description:
Mallanganee Lookout is a scenic lookout located on the edge of the Great Dividing Range in New South Wales, Australia. It offers stunning views of the surrounding countryside, including the Manning Valley, the Barrington Tops National Park, and the Pacific Ocean.

The lookout is easily accessible by car, and there is a short walking path that leads to the top of the hill. The lookout is also equipped with picnic tables and barbecue facilities, making it a great place to enjoy a meal or snack while taking in the views.

properties.name: Maclean Lookout
properties.description: The reserve has long been Maclean's Scenic Lookout and is largely undisturbed with the exception of the cleared area surrounding the lookout, the area adjacent to the communications tower and the Pinnacle. Maclean Lookout Reserve has a high level of historical value in terms of being the site for the town Scenic Lookout where the community have traditionally enjoyed views of the Clarence River, Lake Wooloweyah and the hinterland.

properties.name: Lockyers Road Walking Track
properties.description: Lockyers Road Walking Track is one of the most historic walking tracks in the Blue Mountains. The track is one of the original 'roads' used to descend into Hartley Vale. Hand built by convicts, remnants of their handiwork can still be seen all along the track. The track has beautiful views over the Hartley Valley, and spectacular birdlife.

properties.name: Lake Wyangan
properties.description:
Lake Wyangan is a reservoir in the Waimate District of New Zealand. It is located approximately 20 kilometres (12 mi) south of the town of Waimate, and is the largest lake in the South Island by surface area.

The lake was formed in 1962 by the damming of the Waiho River. It is used for a variety of purposes, including irrigation, water supply, recreation, and hydroelectric power generation.

properties.name: Lake Albert
properties.description: Lake Albert is one of Wagga's most popular recreational facilities, it caters for boating, fishing, swimming and other aquatic activities. Around the shore of Lake Albert you will find a five-and-a-half kilometre circuit walking track, commonly used by walkers, joggers and bike riders. Eight fitness stations have been installed in four locations along the walking track on the eastern side of Lake Albert. Set over 800 metres, the fitness stations are very popular with users of the lake.

properties.name: Koala Hospital
properties.description:
The Koala Hospital in Port Macquarie, New South Wales is the world's first hospital dedicated solely to the care and rehabilitation of koalas. It has been rescuing and rehabilitating koalas since 1973, and has treated over 40,000 koalas to date.

The Koala Hospital is a non-profit organization that relies on donations and volunteers to operate. It provides a safe and supportive environment for koalas to heal and recover from injuries and illnesses. Once koalas are rehabilitated, they are released back into the wild.

The Koala Hospital is also a popular tourist destination, and visitors can learn about koalas and their conservation needs through educational tours and exhibits.

properties.name: Kiama Coast Walk
properties.description: Kiama Coast Walk is a stunning 7.5-kilometre coastal trail in Kiama, New South Wales, Australia. The walk winds its way along the dramatic coastline, offering breathtaking views of the Pacific Ocean, towering cliffs, and secluded beaches. The Kiama Coast Walk is well-maintained and suitable for all fitness levels. There are several access points along the trail, so you can choose to walk the entire trail or just a section of it.

properties.name: Khancoban Pondage
properties.description: Khancoban Pondage is a three kilometre long lake that forms part of the Snowy Mountains Hydro Scheme and around its foreshores lays the town of Khancoban, a town built specifically to house the workers of the Snowy Mountains Scheme, which commenced in 1949.

properties.name: Jenolan Caves
properties.description:
The Jenolan Caves are a system of limestone caves located in the Blue Mountains of New South Wales, Australia. They are the oldest and largest caves in Australia, and are home to a variety of impressive calcite formations.

The caves were formed over millions of years by the erosion of limestone by water. The limestone was deposited by ancient seas that once covered the area. Over time, the water dissolved the limestone and created a network of caves.

The Jenolan Caves are open to the public for tours. Visitors can see a variety of different caves, each with its own unique features. Some of the most popular caves include:
- The Lucas Cave: This cave is home to a variety of delicate calcite formations, including the famous "Bridal Veil".
- The Cathedral Cave: This cave is known for its high ceilings and impressive acoustics.
- The Orient Cave: This cave is home to a variety of colorful formations, including the "Rainbow Pool"

properties.name: Hume Park
properties.description: Hume Park is located on the backwaters of Lake Burrinjuck and was established in 1927. It was developed to commemorate the epic crossing of the flooded Murrumbidgee River by the Hume and Hovell expedition in October 1824. Brief details of this event are on a stone cairn near the boat ramp.

properties.name: Hume and Hovell Walking Track
properties.description:
Follow a route steeped in Australian colonial and Indigenous history; escape is just a few steps away.

Perfect for day-trippers, short walks and long-distance hikers, trail runners and ultra-marathon racers, the 426km Hume & Hovell Track stretches across South-Eastern NSW, from Yass to Albury.

Finishing at the Murray and passing the Murrumbidgee and the Tumut rivers – the long-distance track traverses boardwalks, single track, fire trails and quiet back-country roads, following the historic route of the two explorers after which it’s named.

Stop in for a short stroll with the kids, set out for a day of walking amongst nature, or stretch your legs and pack the tent for a multi-day wilderness adventure. The fully signposted route crosses more than 100 footbridges, runs along rivers’ edges and through cool-climate forests, with 17 dedicated campsites and picturesque picnic spots along the trail.

Surround yourself with quintessentially Australian sclerophyll forests of eucalypts, wattles and banksias, up steep climbs to sweeping views of the valleys below, along boardwalks crossing rich swamplands and or along clear streams of snowmelt, tumbling from the mountains beyond.

properties.name: Horton Falls
properties.description:
Horton Falls is a picturesque natural wonder nestled in a lush, remote valley. Located in a tranquil forested area, this 9 meter cascading waterfall captivates visitors with its pristine beauty. 

Surrounded by dense foliage and vibrant flora, it offers a serene escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. The soothing sound of rushing water and the vibrant greenery make Horton Falls a perfect destination for nature enthusiasts seeking tranquility and scenic charm.

properties.name: Hazeldean at Quandary Ariah Park and Temora
properties.description:
Enjoy an old-fashioned morning tea served on English bone china in the gardens of "Hazeldean" at Quandary, just off Burley Griffin Way, 22 kilometres west of Temora and 14 kilometres east of Ariah Park.

Look through the two railway carriages used in award-winning, tourism accredited Country Carriage Bed and Break...

properties.name: Hanging Rock
properties.description: A prominent landmark of Nowra, offering spectacular views of the Shoalhaven and the town. 46.25 meters above the river, the precariously positioned overhanging rock formation can best be seen from the Bens Walk lookout.

properties.name: Griffith Lookout
properties.description:
Griffith Lookout is a popular tourist destination in Griffith, New South Wales, Australia. It is located on the top of Mount Banaroo, and offers stunning views of the city, surrounding countryside, and the Snowy Mountains in the distance.

The lookout is accessible by car or on foot. The walk to the top is challenging but rewarding, and takes about 30 minutes. Once you reach the top, you can enjoy the views from the viewing platform, or take a walk along the summit trail.

properties.name: Grafton Heritage Trail
properties.description:
Grafton, the Jacaranda City, is blessed with broad avenues, magnificent architecture and spectacular purple flowering jacaranda trees. 

Walking or cycling along their streets gives visitors the opportunity to absorb and feel Grafton's heritage and history in an appropriately quiet and reflective manner. 

Grafton's famous Bendy Bridge, built-in 1915, has a walkway which is a wonderful way to experience the mighty Clarence River, especially at sundown. 

Grafton was the early centre of development in the Clarence Valley being gazetted as a municipality in 1859 and was declared a city in 1885. 

Many buildings have been classified by the National Trust including the notorious Grafton Gaol and the Christ Church Cathedral.

properties.name: Gerringong Falls Walk
properties.description:
The Gerringong Falls Walk is a short and easy bushwalk that leads to a beautiful waterfall in the Illawarra region of New South Wales. The walk starts and ends at the Gerringong Falls Picnic Area, which has a car park, toilets, and picnic tables. The walk follows a well-maintained track through the forest, with a few steps and inclines. 

After about 10 minutes, you will reach the waterfall viewing platform. The waterfall is 26 meters high and cascades over a rocky ledge into a pool below. There are also several other lookouts along the walk, where you can enjoy views of the waterfall and the surrounding forest. The walk is suitable for all ages and fitness levels, and takes around 30 minutes to complete (return).

properties.name: Frog Rock
properties.description: Frog Rock is a natural granite rock formation by the side of the road in the shape of a crouching frog, situated on the Ulan Road. Frog Rock is 19 kilometres from Mudgee and 24 kilometres from Gulgong. The granite from this area was used in the construction of the new Parliament House in Canberra.

properties.name: Fort Bourke Hill Lookout and Open Cut Mine
properties.description: Fort Bourke Hill stands to the east of the Cobar township and rising to 300 metres above sea level, it affords the visitor a wonderful vista of the Cobar landscape. See the open pit and entrance to the underground mine from a well constructed viewing platform.

properties.name: Sealy Lookout Forest Sky Pier
properties.description:
The Forest Sky Pier is located at Sealy Lookout, within Bruxner Park Flora Reserve, Orara East State Forest - only five kilometres from Coffs Harbour. 

The Forest Sky Pier offers the visitor an amazing panoramic view from mountains to the Coffs Harbour coastline. The Pier extends 21 metres out from the Lookout.

properties.name: Fitzroy Falls
properties.description:
Fitzroy Falls offers a spectacular national park experience. 

Just park up at the visitor centre and take the sealed walk to the waterfall - it is pram and wheelchair accessible. 

In addition to the magnificent waterfall, it is a great place to experience a lyrebird singing along one of the walking tracks, vistas into the rainforest gullies of Morton National Park from one or more of the many lookouts, or even a bush picnic by the creek.

properties.name: Eden Gardens Display and Sculpture Walk
properties.description: Eden Gardens Display and Sculpture Walk is a unique outdoor art experience located in Macquarie Park, Sydney, Australia. The walk features a collection of over 35 sculptures by Australian and international artists, set against the backdrop of Eden Gardens' award-winning display gardens.

properties.name: Echo Point Lookout
properties.description:
Echo Point Lookout is perched on the edge of the escarpment, on the traditional land of the Gundungurra and Darug People - the Echo Point precinct. 

Part of the Prince Henry Cliff Walk, it provides panoramic views of the southern Blue Mountains, Kanangra-Boyd Wilderness, and the iconic Three Sisters from a variety of lookouts.

properties.name: Dolphin Marine Magic
properties.description:
Dolphin Marine Magic is famous for its activities and exhibits, where guests enjoy many options for a fun filled experience.
Dolphin Marine Magic is the only zoological park in New South Wales exhibiting dolphins, and the two daily presentations are the Coffs Coast region's star attraction.

properties.name: Dangar Falls
properties.description:
Dangar Falls is a 100-metre waterfall located in Dangar State Forest in New South Wales, Australia. It is one of the tallest waterfalls in the state and is a popular tourist destination. 

The falls are divided into two sections, the Upper Dangar Falls and the Lower Dangar Falls. The Upper Dangar Falls are the tallest, and they plunge over a series of cliffs. The Lower Dangar Falls are wider, and they cascade over a series of rocks.

properties.name: Cook Park Heritage Walk
properties.description: The Cook Park Heritage Walk is a self-guided 1.5-kilometre loop walk that takes you through the park, past some of its most significant historical features. The walk starts at the Cook Park Visitors Centre and follows a path that winds through the park, past the original caretaker's cottage, the Blowes Conservatory, the German "Whiz Bang Gun", and the lattice fernery.

properties.name: Chichester Dam
properties.description: Chichester Dam is a concrete gravity dam located on the Chichester River, approximately 50 kilometres northwest of Dungog in the Hunter Region of New South Wales, Australia. It was built between 1917 and 1926 and is the oldest major concrete dam in the state.

properties.name: Camel Rock
properties.description:
Five minutes drive north from Bermagui along Wallaga Lake Road will bring you to the turn off to Camel Rock. 

This striking rock formation was identified and named by Bass and Flinders during the first mapping of the coastline of the colony of New South Wales.

properties.name: Broulee Island Walk
properties.description: The four kilometre Broulee Island Walk begins south of the main beach at Broulee, across a permanent sand bar. The walk features ocean vistas across pristine rock pools that photographers will love. It's also a great vantage point for whale watching over spring.

properties.name: Box Cutting Rainforest Walk
properties.description: The beautiful Box Cutting Rainforest Walk takes 35 minutes of easy walking, although there are some steep sections. The walk is accessed from Kianga Road on Tourist Drive 4 (Princes Highway, Narooma) and is situated in the Bodalla State Forest along Box Cutting Road.

properties.name: Birdwing Butterfly Walk
properties.description:
The Birdwing Butterfly Walk is a 2.3-kilometre paved walk located in the Richmond Escarpment National Park in New South Wales, Australia. The walk winds through patches of rainforest, marshland, and open areas, and it is a great place to see the Richmond Birdwing butterfly, one of the largest butterflies in Australia. 

The walk is also home to a variety of other wildlife, including platypus, turtles, and birds. There are several picnic areas along the walk, making it a great place to enjoy a meal or snack in the outdoors.

properties.name: Bendethera Caves Walking Trek
properties.description:
The Bendethera Caves Walking Trek is only accessible by four wheel drive via Moruya. It is part of the Deua National Park; a stunning and rugged part of Eurobodalla. The walking trail itself is an eight kilometre round trip with some dramatic terrain in its final stages. 

If you decide to access the caves, appropriate headgear, footwear and torches are essential. 

The walking trail meanders along, following and crossing Con Creek many times, with the peaceful sound of bubbling, flowing water. The endemic Bendethera Wattle can be found approximately three kilometres into the walk, unique to the limestone soils of the Deua National Park. 

Exciting four wheel drive tracks abound with animal and bird sightings common. To enjoy the area for a few nights, stay at the camp ground nearby that offer a peaceful nights rest.

properties.name: Backroads Trail
properties.description:
The Backroads Trail is a new touring route profiling the very best of contemporary rural culture and is situated between Echuca-Moama, Barham and Deniliquin in south western NSW. 

The trail encompasses the rolling plains country between these three towns and features several farm gate enterprises (everything from olive producers to avocado growers to potters and cellar doors) as well as a selection of interpretive panels providing stories and background information about local history and events, farming practices, indigenous heritage, and local flora and fauna.

properties.name: Animals on Bikes
properties.description:
Animals on Bikes is a 120km "Paddock Art" sculpture tourist trail located in Central NSW between Molong and the Dubbo Zoo, via Cumnock and Yeoval. 

This self-drive tourist route is FREE, OPEN all year and viewed from the comfort of your own car.

properties.name: Andersons Fire Trail
properties.description: Anderson Fire Trail runs from Bedford Creek near Woodford to Kings Tableland at Wentworth Falls and is suitable for mountain biking and walking. The Trail also provides access to Murphys Glen and Ingar Picnic Area which is a popular campsite and picnic area.

properties.name: Killen Falls Nature Walks
properties.description:
Killen Falls is a beautiful waterfall located in the Northern Rivers region of New South Wales. The falls are a popular spot for hiking and swimming, and the surrounding rainforest is home to a variety of native plants and animals.

There are two walking trails at Killen Falls:

The Killen Falls Viewing Platform Walk is a short, 660-metre return walk that takes you to a viewpoint overlooking the falls. This is a good option for families and people with limited mobility. The Killen Falls Base Walk is a 1-kilometre return walk that takes you to the base of the falls. This walk is a bit more challenging, as it involves some steep sections. The best time to visit Killen Falls is during the wet season (October to April), when the falls are flowing at their fullest. However, the falls are also beautiful during the dry season (May to September).

properties.name: Fisherman's Lookout
properties.description: Fisherman's Lookout is accessible through the Cape Byron Walking Track. From the beach, go up to a small tower to get to this lookout point. There is a nearby car park available but fees apply. Nice views of the ocean!

properties.name: Cangai Bridge Campground
properties.description: Large riverside camping area with no facilities. There is no fishing, only some swimming and cows attend the area for grazing. Overall very charming but basic place.

properties.name: Waves Campground
properties.description:
At Waves Campground you will be camping in beautiful, untouched and natural surroundings, whilst enjoying the comfort of quality campground amenities. The campground is kept as natural as possible and it won’t take long before you encounter some wildlife. Goannas, possums, kangaroos, and many native bird species feel right at home here with us. Our amenity building provides campers with clean toilets, hot showers and laundry facilities.
Most of our campsites have a picnic table and fire pit. There is a large, sheltered Bush Kitchen with barbecues and many picnic tables available for all guests. The campground office and shop hours are from 9:00am to 6:00 pm every day. In the shop we sell drinks, ice creams, snacks, toiletries, essential groceries and camping supplies such as ice, butane gas and firewood. In the surf shop you can get wetsuits, body boards and surfboards suitable for all ability levels. We also sell surf equipment such as boards, fins, wax and leg ropes. If you are looking for any advice or guidance on surfing in general or the best spots in our area, please talk to our very experienced staff.
properties.fees: unpowered site $10-15 (per person) +  power ($5 to $15) Depends on size of the group (Small Group is $5 and a Large Group is $15)

properties.name: Dangar Falls Lodge
properties.description:
This campground is located 50 metres past the Dangar Falls car park turn off.There is a driveway on the right hand side next to the ‘Dangar Falls Lodge’. Caravans, campervans and tents may camp behind the Lodge via this driveway and through a gate. Contact the owners for availability, camping costs and conditions regarding pets on (02) 6657 2131. Owners will come and collect camping fees.

Facilities include : Picnic tables : Fireplaces : Toilets : Hot showers : Water : Power – this is limited and you need to have your own electrical lead : Dogs are OK – conditions apply : Suitable for small to medium caravans only.

properties.name: Bringagee Reserve
properties.description:
Nice clearing near the river, it's not far from the road, there is a big sandbar/island. River was going down so not many bites tho. 
Peaceful and easy to get to the river.

properties.name: Evans Lookout
properties.description:
Evans Lookout serves as a captivating gateway to the enchanting realm of the Blue Mountains National Park. 

From this vantage point, you can savor awe-inspiring vistas that extend into the depths of Grose Valley, particularly during the golden hour when the sandstone cliff walls emanate a vibrant orange hue as the sun sets. Situated in proximity to Blackheath, it conveniently fits into a day trip itinerary from Sydney. 

Ensuring inclusivity, there's an accessible pathway designed for individuals with mobility challenges, ensuring that the breathtaking views are accessible to all.

properties.name: Newey Reservoir
properties.description:
*** No free camping)***
Parking along the reservoir, some shade and a toilet block. Popular place but quiet. 2km out of Cobar. There is a cycle / walking path into town.

properties.name: Murwillumbah Showground
properties.description: Self contained vehicles can stay here for a maximum of two consecutive nights.

properties.name: Sydney Harbour Top Deck Lunch Cruise
properties.description:
Cruise aboard Sydney Harbour on Sydney's flagship MV Sydney 2000

Enjoy stunning views of Sydney Harbour from the upper deck with optional guranteed window seating, superb dining and attentive service.

properties.name: Dairy Park Farm Stay Bed and Breakfast
properties.description: Dairy Park is a working farm set in the picturesque rolling hills of the central tablelands. There are three self-contained uniquely separate units: the Cabin and Thummy Jacks and the Shearers Hut.

properties.name: Govetts Leap Lookout
properties.description:
Govetts Leap Lookout is a mesmerizing gem nestled in the Blue Mountains of Australia. 

Perched on the edge of sheer cliffs, it offers breathtaking panoramic views of the Grose Valley and its cascading waterfalls. Towering eucalyptus trees surround the lookout, creating a dramatic frame for the natural masterpiece below. 

Witness the landscape's ever-changing hues, from lush greenery to deep blue haze, especially stunning at sunrise or sunset. This iconic spot also holds cultural significance for indigenous communities. 

It's a short stroll from the car park, making it an accessible and awe-inspiring stop for any traveler exploring the Blue Mountains.

properties.name: Yamba Central
properties.description:
Yamba Central hostel resides on the NSW mid-north coast, making it a great stop off between Sydney and Brisbane. 

This seaside town has fantastic beaches and the most famous surf breaks.

properties.name: Wollondilly River Station
properties.description:
Wollondilly River Station offers pet friendly family bush camping.

The Wollondilly River around Goodman's Ford has been operating since 1968 as a family operated private camping ground.  Throughout the years their policy has remained the same - providing good and affordable pet-friendly family bush camping.

properties.name: Orange Backpackers
properties.description:
Backpacker accommodation in the heart of fruit country. Orange Backpackers, run by Claire Hordern, is located in Nashdale, just 10 minutes outside of Orange and right in the heart of food and wine country where plenty of farm work is available in the surrounding area.

With functional power, plumbing, barbecue, wi...

properties.name: Burrumbuttock Primitive Camping Ground
properties.description: Burrumbuttock Primitive Camping Ground is a low cost camping option for visitors to the Burrumbuttock district. The camping ground is located at the Burrumbuttock Hall, where visitors can stay for 48 hours with an unpowered site.

properties.name: Wattle Flat Camping Area - Styx River State Forest
properties.description: This large, grassy and shaded camping area with basic amenities is located on the bank of the river, among trees. Here you will find walking tracks, fishing spots and plenty of water sports opportunities. 4WD recommended.

properties.name: Narromine Rest Area
properties.description: This circular overnight rest area with toilets and a camp kitchen is located off the highway. There are a few trees, which will give you shade and shelter. Suitable for big rigs.

properties.name: Mundoonan No.2 Rest Area
properties.description: This drive-through rest area with good facilities is located off the Hume Hwy and has limited shade. It is accessible for the northbound traffic and is frequented by trucks.

properties.name: Mundoonan No.1 Rest Area
properties.description: This drive-through rest area with good facilities is located off the Hume Hwy and has limited shade. It is accessible for the southbound traffic and is frequented by trucks.

properties.name: Grenfell Old Railway Station
