properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Shoalhaven Visitor Information Centre Ulladulla
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Port Stephens Visitor Information Centre
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Alstonville Country Cottages
properties.description:
Peaceful camping spot with lovely country views with rainforest walk to Duck Creek. Level, grass camping area with access to shared Bbq, laundry, toilets and swimming pool.
Free wifi provided to guests. Accessible for tents and campervans.

properties.name: Three Sisters Walk
properties.description:
This family-friendly walk treats you to ever-changing views of the grand Three Sisters, rising nearly a kilometre above sea level.

Pass through the archway, next to the Echo Point Visitor Centre, and you'll soon be surrounded by soaring eucalypt forest, bird calls and fresh mountain air. Keep an eye out for the superb lyrebird and crimson rosellas as you walk the gently sloping path for 400m to Oreades lookout. Marvel at the incredible views of the Three Sisters' weather-eroded sandstone turrets, and the hazy 'blue' Jamison Valley stretching to Mount Solitary.

From here, steps lead a further 50m to Lady Game lookout, for a closer view of this remarkable rock formation. A short but very steep set of stairs at the top of the Giant Stairway leads to Honeymoon Bridge, which connects to the first sister.

On the way back, enjoy the short signposted detour to Spooners lookout.

properties.name: Shelley Beach
properties.description: This is a popular naturist beach

properties.name: Wooli Beach
properties.description: If you're looking to enjoy water, wildlife and natural wonders, Wooli Beach is the place for you. This secluded beach is surrounded by Yuraygir National Park and offers a story book setting for rest and relaxation.

properties.name: Wagga Beach
properties.description:
Wagga Wagga Beach is located on the banks of the beautiful Murrumbidgee River, in the centre of the inland City of Wagga Wagga. It is very popular during the summer months, when the temperature is climbing. 

You can relax on the shaded lawn, picnic on the banks of the river or go for a swim.

properties.name: Umina Beach
properties.description:
Umina Beach is located in the southern coastline of the Central Coast, on the Peninsula. Umina Beach has excellent surfing conditions, choppy in strong southerlies. 

The Umina Beach Surf Life Saving Club has been on site since 1959. 

The beach is patrolled every weekend.

properties.name: Toowoon Bay Beach
properties.description: Located just a five minute drive south-east of The Entrance, Toowoon Bay is one of the Central Coast's best kept secrets.  It offers a picturesque horseshoe shaped protected beach that is great for families, but bathers should be careful of currents near the rocks at the southern end.

properties.name: Short Point Beach
properties.description:
Short Point Beach (Tura Beach) has some of the best coastal views on the Sapphire Coast and is popular with walkers, surfers, divers and those who just love to relax on the sand or the grassy foreshore. The headland includes amenities and a lookout platform, as well as sun deck chairs which enhance the laid-back coastal feel! 

A short walk down the cliff from the car park gives quick access to the beach. The grassy reserve area includes a signposted off-leash dog walking area, so your pooch can run wild and enjoy the sea air.

properties.name: Scotts Head Beach
properties.description: At the southern end of Nambucca Shire, Scotts Head is an idyllic place for families to visit. The sands of Main Beach stretch for miles to the north making it the perfect place to enjoy a solitary walk, build a sandcastle, paddle in clear water or run across sand so clean it squeaks beneath your feet.

properties.name: Sapphire Beach
properties.description: Just north of Coffs Harbour, there are a few access points to the beach - take Sapphire Beach exit and access it via Crystal Waters drive, which offers playground facilities, parking and beach showers

properties.name: Saltwater and Wallabi Point Beaches
properties.description: The adjacent beaches of Saltwater Beach and Wallabi Point Beach are separated by Saltwater Point within Saltwater National Park. These beaches, just south of Old Bar, are perfect for surfing enthusiasts and attract thousands of tourists every year who are in search the perfect wave. These beaches are also great for families as there is a warm, shallow saltwater lagoon nestled against the picnic reserve, providing excellent swimming opportunities in Khappinghat Creek.
properties.town: Old Bar - Manning Point - Red Head

properties.name: Redhead Beach
properties.description: Redhead Beach is at the northern end of a nine mile stretch of coastline, and is known for its stunning cliffs, rocky outcrops and shark tower. Redhead is patrolled in the warmer months, is home to the Redhead Surf Life Saving Club, and is popular with swimmers and surfers alike.

properties.name: Pambula Beach
properties.description: The sweeping sands of Pambula Beach are ideal for walking and beach combing. Collect shells washed up with the tide and explore the fascinating rock pools. Lunch with the kangaroos or take a horse ride through the local wetlands and river flats.

properties.name: North Beach Recreation and Bowling Club
properties.description:
North Beach Recreation and Bowling Club is located at Mylestom, on the banks of the Bellinger River where the river meets the sea. 

The Friendly Club provides a comfortable and quiet haven surrounded by nature perfect for relaxation.
 
Come and enjoy the wide range of facilities including both Chinese and Pizza din...

properties.name: Newcastle Beach
properties.description: Newcastle Beach has a reputation for being one of the best surf locations in Australia and is a favoured spot for board riders wishing to catch that perfect wave off Newcastle Point. Lifeguard Services are provided seven days a week during swimming season.

properties.name: Narrabeen Beach
properties.description: Narrabeen Beach is one of Australia's iconic surfing and swimming beaches. Over three kilometres of sand stretch from Long Reef in the south to the Narrabeen Lagoon entrance in the north, with four surf lifesaving clubs along the beach providing qualified, volunteer lifesaver patrols to protect swimmers.

properties.name: Nambucca Heads Beach
properties.description:
Nambucca Heads is the accommodation and entertainment hub of the beautiful Nambucca Valley region and neighbouring beach communities, with beaches well suited for beginner surfers. 

The ocean beaches are Main Beach, Shelly Beach, Beilbys Beach and South Beach, which is in the Gaagal Wanggaan (South Beach) National Park. South Beach is for experienced board riders.

properties.name: Mollymook Surf Beach
properties.description: Mollymook is a popular family beach with the best parks and safest bathing at the southern end around the Surf Club. Surfers will enjoy the southern reef when it is working and the beach breaks. Best conditions for surfing are light north-west to south-west winds, peaking at a three metre groundswell.

properties.name: Main Beach Byron Bay
properties.description:
With stunning views of distant mountains and passing whales and dolphins, these white sandy beaches have a northerly aspect. 



Main Beach is dominated by the Surf Club and is patrolled by Surf Lifesavers in summer. It is only a short stroll to Byron Bay town centre.

properties.name: Lighthouse Beach
properties.description: Lighthouse Beach is seven kilometres south of Port Macquarie, and is a nine kilometre stretch of south-east facing sand heading to Lake Cathie. It is a favourite surf beach offering protection from the summer north easterlies.

properties.name: Killick Beach
properties.description: Killick Beach is 14 kilometres long at Crescent Head is a picturesque white sand beach that is home to the Crescent Head Malibu Classic. Famous for a long, slow right-hand wave that peels off the point, working in almost any sized swell it is best suited to longboards.

properties.name: Jetty Beach
properties.description: Jetty Beach is a protected beach which is popular with both locals and tourists alike, especially families. Where the green meets the gold you will find the Jetty Foreshores Park. The park has showers, toilets, barbecues, popular picnic shelter areas, pathways for roller blades and bicycles and children's playground.

properties.name: Hyams Beach
properties.description: Hyams Beach is one of the most popular of the myriad bays and beaches inside the Jervis Bay area. Facing east and looking directly at Point Perpendicular, Hyams rarely receives any swell other than a gentle shore break in a north-easter, making it a safe family beach.

properties.name: Hawks Nest Beach
properties.description: Hawks Nest Beach also known as Bennetts Beach, is the beginning of a long stretch of beach, which enters the Myall Lakes National Park and extends north to the fishing village of Seal Rocks through a virtual wildlife corridor.

properties.name: Duranbah Beach
properties.description: "Dee-bah", as it's known locally, is the most northerly beach in NSW; walk a few metres up onto the headland here on a summer's day and you'll find yourself in Queensland and in a different time-zone. Less than 200 metres in length, Duranbah is somewhat unheralded.

properties.name: Dixon Park Beach
properties.description:
Dixon Park Beach has Council Lifeguard Services provided Monday to Saturday during swimming season and volunteer members of Dixon Park Surf Lifesaving Club providing beach patrols on Sundays during the swimming season.



There is a sheltered picnic table area and change room facilities available. Plus free electric bbqs.

properties.name: Delicate Beach
properties.description: Delicate campground, in Goolawah Regional Park near Crescent Head, offers beach camping and caravan camping and welcomes those camping with dogs. It’s the ideal Kempsey region camping spot.

properties.name: Culburra Surf Beach
properties.description: Culburra Surf Beach and it's neighbour Warrain Beach are joined by Penguin Head (a great lookout for spotting passing whales and resident seals) . There is a surf club nearby, and the beach is patrolled in Summer. This beach is not recommended for families with small children or swimmers who are new to ocean swimming.

properties.name: Catherine Hill Bay Beach
properties.description:
Catherine Hill Bay Beach will not be patrolled from 29 April 2024 to 27 September 2024. The summer swimming season will recommence 28 September 2024. 
Catherine Hill Bay is largely untouched by development, and the coastline looks as it would have 100 years ago, with a stunning beach, popular for fishing, surfing and swimming.

properties.name: Cabarita Beach
properties.description: With large areas of protected wetlands and limited development, this creates a quiet, relaxed holiday atmosphere in Cabarita. Bounded by Nature Reserve to the north and west and the Pacific Ocean to the east, this small coastal village with 3000 residents represents a unique lifestyle.

properties.name: Bondi Beach
properties.description: Bondi Beach is Australia's most famous beach. Bondi's mixture of lifestyles would suit most visitors, whether you're drawn to the fashionable northern end or the surf-crazy south. You'll find that Bondi is one of the better Sydney beaches, simply because it has great surf, good food, and a great atmosphere.

properties.name: Boat Beach
properties.description: Boat beach is the next beach past Seal Rocks No.1 Beach. It is framed by headlands, spectacular rocky outcrops and a steep house peppered mainland. The beach here is nearly always quite flat and suitable for families

properties.name: Maitland Bay
properties.description:
Maitland Bay is a gorgeous beach nestled inside the Bouddi National Park.

It is reached via a walking track (1 hour return) which is steep in parts.

The beach does not have lifeguards patrolling.

properties.name: Armands Beach
properties.description: If swimming and sunbathing in the nude is your preference, Armands Beach was declared legally clothes optional by Bega Valley Shire Council in November 1993. Armands Beach is not patrolled and there are no toilets or facilities. Bring all you need and take away all you bring. Clothes option is limited to the extent of the sands of the beach

properties.name: Anna Bay Beach
properties.description:
The dunes behind Birubi Beach at Anna Bay constitute the largest coastal sand mass in New South Wales and are a popular spot for activities such as quad-biking, sand-boarding and camel rides.



Five minutes’ stroll away is Anna Bay village, which has a supermarket, butcher, fruit and vegetable store, bottle shop etc.

properties.name: Cape Byron Lighthouse
properties.description:
Cape Byron Lighthouse is a popular tourist destination and is accessible by car, bike, or foot. Visitors can climb to the top of the lighthouse for stunning views of Byron Bay, the coastline, and the Pacific Ocean. 

The lighthouse is also home to a small museum, which tells the story of the lighthouse and its keepers. The museum also has exhibits on the area's history and wildlife. 

This area can be reached by Cape Byron Walking Track if you don't wanna pay for the car park's fee (there's a car park right next to the lighthouse).

properties.name: Avalon Beach
properties.description: Avalon Beach is a great beach with good waves and a pool in the ocean.

properties.name: Forbes Holiday Park
properties.description: Our peaceful caravan park is a delight to your senses, with lush grass and something for everyone. Explore the picturesque NSW central coast with our caravan park as your base, with Parkes, Cowra, Dubbo and Condobolin just a short distance away.

properties.name: Coopernook Hotel Parking
properties.description: You can stand up to three nights at this RV friendly hotel. Support the hotel by enjoying the bistro meals or their bar service. Lunch is available seven days a week from 12 until 2 o'clock and dinner from Tuesday to Saturday from six to 8 o'clock. Pull up on the grassy area beside the hotel or behind the hotel. Don't camp on the graveled area, which is a council reserve. There is a toilet with disability access off the hotel patio for hotel customers only. The reserve, not the hotel camping area, has free gas barbecues, a sheltered picnic tables, rubbish bins, a boat ramp and jetty.

properties.name: Mountain Top Rest Area
properties.description: Small, sealed rest area. Toilets and covered picnic table available. 4km S of Dorrigo, signposted.

properties.name: Foreshore Caravan Park
properties.description: Choice of powered or unpowered sites many with absolute water frontage.Amenities block conveniently situated and maintained to a high standard.Cabins available for holiday or overnight stay some with great water views.

properties.name: Southern Cross Motor Inn and Tourist Park
properties.description:
For some of the best value snow accommodation, meals, and ski packages look no further than the Southern Cross Motor Inn and Tourist Park. 

Southern Cross Motor Inn is a family business committed to offering the best service in the Snowy Mountains. They are open all year round and ready to treat you to 'good old' camping esperience.

properties.name: Tuross Lakeside Tourist Park
properties.description:
Tuross Lakeside Tourist Park: Your Perfect South Coast Getaway

Escape to the idyllic waters of Tuross Lake at Tuross Lakeside Tourist Park, your one-stop destination for a relaxing South Coast escape. Our park boasts absolute lake frontage, offering stunning views and pristine waters for the whole family.

Choose from our range of comfortable accommodations, including waterfront cabins, some featuring luxurious spas, or set up camp on our generous grassy sites by the beach.  Whether you're a keen angler, a water sport enthusiast, or simply seeking a nature escape, Tuross Lakeside caters to all.  Spend your days soaking up the sun, swimming in the lake, or launching your boat from our private ramp.  Enjoy the serenity or explore the surrounds - the choice is yours!

Unwind and reconnect at Tuross Lakeside Tourist Park.  Book your stay today!

properties.name: Boydtown Caravan Park
properties.description:
Boydtown Beach Holiday Park. Your Perfect Eden Escape (NSW).

Experience a relaxing getaway at Boydtown Beach Holiday Park, a 4.5-star caravan and camping park ideally situated on the pristine shores of Twofold Bay in Eden, Sapphire Coast NSW.

Unwind on 1km of beachfront with stunning ocean views and enjoy easy access to the area's natural wonders, including whale watching (between September and November), snorkelling, fishing, and scenic nature walks.

The park boasts a range of amenities for a comfortable stay.  Extra-large powered and unpowered sites.  Modern camp kitchens (indoor and outdoor).  Up-to-date amenities blocks with disability access.  Family bathroom and laundry facilities.  Cricket/football field. Bike path for the kids to explore safely.

properties.name: Mulberry Vale Cabins
properties.description:
Mulberry Vale Cabins: Outback Retreat near Broken Hill, NSW.

Experience the charm of outback Australia at Mulberry Vale Cabins, a unique pet-friendly accommodation located just 5km from Broken Hill, NSW.

Our 10 fully self-contained cabins offer a relaxing escape ideal for groups, families or couples. Enjoy stunning sunrises, encounters with resident kangaroos, and the serenity of the outback, all within easy reach of Broken Hill's many attractions.

properties.name: Woronora Village Tourist Park
properties.description:
Escape to a peaceful riverside retreat at Woronora Village Tourist Park in Sydney's Sutherland Shire.

Nestled along the scenic Woronora River, Woronora Village offers a variety of comfortable accommodation options, from self-contained cabins ideal for families and couples, to caravan and camping sites perfect for nature lovers.

Just a 45-minute drive south of Sydney's CBD, this Sutherland Shire accommodation provides a tranquil base to explore the surrounding natural beauty. Enjoy fishing, kayaking, or bushwalking right on the park's doorstep.

properties.name: Outback Villas
properties.description:
Outback Villas: Your Broken Hill Oasis.
Discover comfort and relaxation at Outback Villas, your perfect base to explore Broken Hill and surrounds. Our self-contained villas offer a tranquil escape, conveniently located just 400 metres from Westside Plaza Shopping Centre and a short drive to Broken Hill’s vibrant town centre.

Unwind in style.  Outback Villas provides a variety of fully-equipped villas in Broken Hill, NSW, suitable for couples, families or groups. Enjoy the privacy of your villa featuring comfortable beds, a well-equipped kitchen, and laundry facilities. Relax by the BBQ area or unwind in the sparkling swimming pool (seasonal).

Explore Broken Hill

Outback Villas is the ideal location for those wanting to discover the natural beauty and rich history of Broken Hill. Visit iconic landmarks like the Silver City and explore the surrounding outback landscape.

properties.name: Camp Jordon
properties.description: Camp Jordon has a variety of accommodation options to suit, including deluxe bell tents, self-contained cabins offering river views, renovated airstream caravans and refurbished shipping containers. Each room is designed with rest and relaxation in mind with optimum adventure available at your doorstep. We are also pet friendly and would love to chat with you about booking in to our pet friendly accommodation options. An additional cleaning fee will be applied for pet friendly accommodation.

properties.name: El Lago Waters Tourist Park
properties.description:
El Lago Waters Tourist Park: Your Central Coast Lakeside Escape.

El Lago Waters Tourist Park offers a relaxing getaway in The Entrance, Central Coast, New South Wales. Nestled beside the beautiful Tuggerah Lakes, our park caters to a variety of travellers, from campers and caravan enthusiasts to those seeking comfortable cabins.

properties.name: Nyngan Riverside Tourist Park
properties.description:
Looking for comfortable and affordable accommodation in Nyngan, NSW? Look no further than Nyngan Riverside Tourist Park! On the banks of the picturesque Bogan River, our park offers a relaxing escape ideal for travellers of all kinds.

We boast spacious, shady grounds (perfect for pitching a tent or parking your caravan) and a variety of cabins to suit your needs. All our sites are powered, and many are drive-thru for added convenience.

Enjoy a dip in the river, cook up a storm on our free BBQs, or relax under the starry outback sky. With amenities like camp kitchens, playgrounds, and clean amenities blocks, Nyngan Riverside Tourist Park has everything for a memorable stay in outback NSW.

properties.name: Batemans Bay Marina Resort
properties.description:
Batemans Bay Marina Resort: Your Waterfront Escape on the NSW South Coast.

Batemans Bay Marina Resort is your idyllic waterfront haven located in the heart of Batemans Bay, New South Wales. Escape to stylish self-contained villas with private verandas, offering stunning views of the crystal-clear bay.

properties.name: Moree Tourist Park
properties.description:
Moree Tourist Park: Your Relaxing Escape in Moree Plains, NSW

Unwind and explore at Moree Tourist Park, a haven for travellers nestled in the heart of the Moree Plains region of New South Wales.

Ideal for all types of travellers, Moree Tourist Park offers comfortable accommodation options ranging from spacious caravan and camping sites to cosy cabins, perfect for families, couples, and solo adventurers.

Situated near the banks of the Mehi River, offering stunning natural beauty.  Close proximity to Moree's famed artesian hot springs, known for their reputed therapeutic qualities.
Moree Tourist Park boasts a saltwater pool for a refreshing dip together with hot and cold thermal spa baths to soothe tired muscles.
BBQ areas for social gatherings under the stars.
Pet-friendly powered and unpowered campsites.

Whether you're seeking a stopover for the night or a base to explore the wonders of the Moree Plains, Moree Tourist Park provides a welcoming and comfortable atmosphere for an unforgettable stay.

properties.name: Kioloa Holiday Cabins
properties.description:
Kioloa Beach Holiday Cabins: Your South Coast Getaway.

Escape to the pristine shores of Kioloa Beach on the idyllic South Coast of New South Wales. Kioloa Beach Holiday Cabins offers comfortable and affordable beachfront accommodation for families and couples.

Nestled amongst six acres of natural beauty, our 12 well-spaced cabins provide privacy and tranquility. Just a short stroll from the golden sands of Kioloa Beach, you can spend your days swimming, fishing, or exploring the nearby Merry Beach.

In the evenings, unwind by the outdoor fireplace or enjoy a BBQ picnic under the star-studded sky. Kioloa Beach Holiday Cabins is also close to popular activities like surfing, diving, and bushwalking, making it the perfect base for your South Coast adventure.

properties.name: Kootingal Kourt Caravan Park
properties.description:
Kootingal Kourt Caravan Park: Your Peaceful Escape in Tamworth

Looking for a comfortable and affordable stay in Tamworth, NSW? Kootingal Kourt Caravan Park is your perfect base camp. Our caravan park is conveniently located alongside the New England Highway, offering easy access to Tamworth's attractions while providing a tranquil atmosphere away from the hustle and bustle.

Choose from our range of accommodation options including powered and unpowered caravan sites. Enjoy spacious grassy sites, some with shade from beautiful trees.
Comfortable cabins: Relax in our cabins that provide all the amenities you need for a relaxing stay.
On-site vans: Our vans are a convenient option for those who want a comfortable stay without bringing their own caravan.
Unwind and enjoy our park's facilities:

Sparkling swimming pool: Take a refreshing dip in our pool, perfect for cooling off on a hot day.  Camp kitchen and BBQ area: Cook up a delicious meal in our camp kitchen and enjoy it outdoors with friends and family.  Immaculate amenities block: Our amenities are always clean and well-maintained for your comfort.

Kootingal Kourt Caravan Park is also:

Pet-friendly: Bring your furry companions along for your stay.
Close to popular attractions: Explore all that Tamworth has to offer, including the Australian Country Music Capital Tamworth.

properties.name: Narrabri Motel and Caravan Park
properties.description:
Narrabri Motel and Caravan Park offer comfortable accommodation for all budgets (ranging from motel rooms, motel suites to park cabins, caravan sites and tent sites as well as a bunk house that sleeps nine).

Just a few minutes drive to town centre, we welcome families, large groups and groups of workers in single or shared accommodation together with off street parking for long and heavy vehicles.

properties.name: Lightning Ridge Outback Resort and Caravan Park
properties.description:
Get the real Aussie Opal Experience in Lightning Ridge, full of ‘larger than life’ characters who have spent their lives living tough, but when you speak to them they wouldn't have it any other way. Lightning Ridge is steep in history & is Black Opal country!

Whether you are towing a caravan, camping or simply wanting a motel room or self-contained cabin. Let us  at Lightning Ridge Outback Resort & caravan park be your next holiday destination. Lightning Ridge is the ideal place for your next outback NSW holiday adventure, the centre of mining for black opal & other opal gemstones. Bring the kids, holiday with your friends or take your staff for a team building trip.

Our complex has a wide range of accommodation options (all with air-conditioning, newly refurbished motel rooms), entertainment areas (onsite hotel bar - the only hotel bar in Lightning Ridge), beer garden, new sunset watching area, outdoor swimming pool and playground, BBQ and dining facilities – we have something for you to enjoy during any season.

Lightning Ridge Outback Resort & Caravan Park is an opal throw away from the town centre & all the local attractions such as hot artesian baths, John Murray's gallery, car door tours, try your luck at fossicking in our own backyard.  There's so much to do and see in the Ridge!

properties.name: Bodalla Park Forest Rest Area
properties.description:
Temporarily closed for maintenance 5 Feb 2024 - 23 Mar 2024  

Shady rest area just off Princes Hwy. Toilets, picnic tables and bins available. Sloping ground, may not be good for caravans. Max stay: 24hrs. Portable water available.

properties.name: Cootamundra Bird Walk
properties.description:
Cootamundra's Bird Walk, a vibrant tapestry of nature's finest. As you tread the winding paths, colorful feathers and melodic tweets surround you. This avian haven is a symphony of crimson rosellas, golden whistlers, and azure kingfishers, each adding a unique note to the air. It's not just a walk; it's a dance with local birdlife. Pause on strategically placed benches, breathe in eucalyptus-scented air, and let curiosity guide you. Whether a seasoned ornithologist or a casual admirer, Cootamundra's Bird Walk promises an immersive encounter with Australia's diverse birdlife, a flight into an avian wonderland. 

Enjoy the bird sculptures made in the Men's Shed. Ones to look out for are Goanna, Ringtail Possum, Superb Parrot, Boobook Owl, Brolga, Rainbow Bee-eater, Tawny Frogmouth, Pied Currawong, Eastern Rosella, Azure Kingfisher and the Blue Faced Honey Eater.

properties.name: Clarence River Wilderness Camp and Lodge
properties.description:
Clarence River Wilderness Lodge is a spectacularly wild and remote off-grid holiday destination, situated on the headwaters of the Clarence River in the rugged Great Dividing Range.

Leave the digital world at the gate while you reconnect to nature, your partner, your friends and your family as you sit around the campfire by the river. Your kids will enjoy having the freedom to ride bikes, swim, canoe and explore the bush like kids have always done.

If camping by the river and waking to the sounds of birds or rising early to spot a platypus are what you have in mind for your wilderness camping holiday, Clarence River Wilderness Lodge is the place for you.

With only a limited number of campsites available you will definitely see some native wildlife and be able to enjoy your own piece of paradise.

With over four thousand hectares of river crafted country preserved in a wildlife refuge that is noted for the diverse abundance of its native animals and the wild splendour of its scenery, it’s hard to believe that this forgotten pocket of Australia is just 3 hours from Brisbane!

Whether you’re after an environmentally sustainable and off-grid holiday destination, an affordable digital detox, or a back-to-nature family or a group camping trip, your hosts, Sharon and Stephen, warmly welcome you to our wilderness retreat.

properties.name: Blue Mountains Adventure Company
properties.description:
Experience Adventure in the Blue Mountain

Just one hundred kilometres west of Sydney, Australia, lies one of nature's most magnificent creations, the World Heritage area of the Blue Mountains. 

Discover endless stretches of sublime natural beauty as you rock climb sandstone cliffs, experience a classic Blue Mountains walk, or abseil into hidden canyons with us - the first company to offer canyoning tours in the Blue Mountains.

properties.name: Wollomombi Falls
properties.description:
Wollomombi Falls is a waterfall located on the Wollomombi River in the New England region of New South Wales, Australia. It is the highest single-drop waterfall in New South Wales, with a total drop of 220 meters (722 feet). 

The falls are located in Oxley Wild Rivers National Park, a remote and rugged area of the New England region. The park is home to a variety of wildlife, including koalas, wombats, and platypuses. 

Wollomombi Falls is a popular tourist destination, but it is important to be aware of the risks involved in visiting. The track to the falls is steep and uneven, and the pool at the bottom of the falls is deep and dangerous. Visitors are advised to wear appropriate footwear and to be careful when swimming.

properties.name: Ilford Rest Area
properties.description: Small and sealed drive-through bay located directly by the main road. Good facilities, a post box and a pay phone are available here.

properties.name: Basic Rest Area
properties.description:
Simple sealed rest area on Sturt Hwy. 

Bins and some shade here, no other facilities. 

Very close to the road so may be some noise. 

11km SE of Sandigo.

properties.name: Pevensey Rest Area
properties.description: Basic area on A20 with few picnic tables and rubbish bins.

properties.name: Bell River Rest Area
properties.description:
Small stopping area, paved. 

Toilets, sheltered picnic tables and rubbish bins available. 

Not sheltered from traffic, heavy road noises.

properties.name: Bookham Rest Area
properties.description:
Small rest area 30km of Jugiong, at Bookham. 

There are toilets, few picnic tables and rubbish bins. 

Unfiltered water. 

About 10 car parks and a bigger parking behind the toilets block.

properties.name: Myall Creek Rest Area
properties.description:
Shady grass camping area next to Myall Creek. 

Picnic tables and rubbish bins available. 

Located on Delungra-Ashford Rd, 24km NE of Bingara.

properties.name: Kyeamba Gap Rest Area
properties.description:
Sealed rest area right on Hume Hwy. 

Toilets, sheltered picnic tables and bins available. 

Shared with trucks. 39km N of Holbrook, Northbound access only. Max stay: 20hrs.

properties.name: Willowvale Rest Area
properties.description:
Rest Area next to highway around 40km from Balranald. 

Large area for trucks and all size vehicles.

Have toilets, rubbish bins and few picnic tables. 

Non-drinkable water.

properties.name: Warialda Rest Area
properties.description:
Large overnight parking area for SC and non-SC. 

Toilet facilities and dump station on site. 

Max stay: 20hrs.

properties.name: Wootton Rest Area
properties.description: It is a gravel car park with an aged, sheltered picnic table and chairs. There are no toilets or other facilities. The quiet refuge only 5 km away from the Pacific Highway.

properties.name: Newell Highway Rest Area
properties.description: Basic roadside rest area with no toilets.

properties.name: Dolo Hill Rest Area
properties.description:
Sealed rest area on Barrier Hwy. 

Drop toilet, sheltered picnic table and bin available. 

Right on the road so could be noisy. 60km W of Wilcannia.

properties.name: Packsaddle Rest Area
properties.description:
Spacious rest area on Silver City Hwy next to Packsaddle Creek. 

Picnic tables available, no shade. 

175km N of Broken Hill. 

Max stay: 24hrs.

properties.name: Wallacetown Rest Area
properties.description:
Sealed rest area on Olympic Hwy. 

Toilet and sheltered picnic tables available, shade from trees. 

Located opposite service station, 23km N of Wagga Wagga. Max stay: 24hrs.

properties.name: Greens Point Camp Area
properties.description:
This is a gem of a spot by the Turon River. 

There are plenty of nearly level campsites and a few at the east end with shade from large trees. There are river rock fire pits, sheltered new picnic tables and wheelchair accessible non-flush toilets (although it would be a slog up the hill in a wheelchair to reach the toilets). 

There is no water other than from rainwater supplied by tanks. 

There are more pretty sites at the west end of the campsite amongst the trees and by the river. There are a few specially labeled sites for small tents.

properties.name: McDonalds Hole Road Rest Area
properties.description:
Shady rest area on Castlereagh Hwy. 

Rubbish bins and picnic tables available, lots of space. 

10km N of Capertee or 15km S of Ilford.

properties.name: Bundaburrah Rest Area
properties.description:
Sealed rest area on the N side of Newell Hwy, set back from the road. 

One picnic table, bins, limited shade. 

Is also used by trucks. 30km SW of Forbes.

properties.name: Lyndabale Rest Area
properties.description: Large gravel rest area on the Newell Hwy. Covered picnic tables and rubbish bins, some shade from trees available. 15km S of Tomingley.

properties.name: Gunnedah North Rest Area
properties.description:
Large basic area with no toilet facilities. 

Rubbish bin, picnic tables. SC only.

properties.name: Bunnan Rest Area
properties.description:
Free camping area at the N end of Bunnan. 

Picnic tables available, limited shade. 

On W side of High St. Max stay: 24hrs.

properties.name: Mundoonen Rest Area - Northbound
properties.description:
Rest area on East side of the Highway, 17km of Gunning. Have toilets, unfiltered water, covered picnic tables and BBQ areas and rubbish bins. 

There is also a little sheltered parking.

Northbound Entry

properties.name: Kibby VC Rest Area
properties.description: Nice, sealed rest area on Federal Highway. Toilets and picnic tables available, limited shade. 14km SW of Goulburn, Southbound access only.

properties.name: Attunga Creek Rest Area
properties.description:
From the south towards Narrandera, turn to boat ramp sign after the bridge. Various camp areas between trees. 

Toilets and rubbish bins. 

Maximum stay: 24 Hours. 

BBQ and picnic tables available near to the boat ramp.

properties.name: Mail Route Rest Area
properties.description: Basic roadside stop on both sides of the road. Toilet, rubbish bin and covered picnic table on site.

properties.name: Yarraman Rest Area
properties.description:
Large parking area suitable for both SC and non-SC. 

Toilets on site, site shared with trucks.

properties.name: Rocky River Fossicking Area
properties.description: Large, quiet campground where you can fossick for gold

properties.name: Caves Turnoff Rest Area
properties.description:
Small rest area a little below the highway. 

Suitable for all kinds of vehicles, long driveway with a few parking bays. 

No toilet facilities. 

Sheltered picnic tables and rubbish bins available.

properties.name: The Aloes Picnic Area
properties.description:
Simple rest area with picnic tables. 

10km E of Kenebri, entry on Gwabegar Baradine Rd.

properties.name: Campbells Reserve Camp Area
properties.description:
Free bush camping on the banks of the Murrumbidgee River. 

No facilities available, SC only.

properties.name: Swamp Creek Camp Area
properties.description:
Nice camping area by the Peel River, with drop toilets, picnic tables and rubbish bins. 

4km N of Nundle via Rivers Rd.

properties.name: Oaky River Rest Area
properties.description:
Basic roadside rest stop with a picnic table and many trees. 

Close to the road, 15km SW of Ebor just past the small Oaky River bridge.

properties.name: Kywong Rest Area
properties.description:
Rest Area 22km (South Est) of Narrandera. Small picnic areas with few tables and rubbish bins. 

No toilets. 

Further to the west is trucks only on this side of the road.

properties.name: Jaron Park Community Hall
properties.description:
Great spot off the highway with flush toilets at the hall. 

Nice views and a good amount of room. Facilities provided by the local community and there is a donation box in the middle of the park.

properties.name: Molong Caravan Park
properties.description:
Welcome to Molong Caravan Park, your ideal destination for affordable and comfortable accommodation in the heart of Cabonne Shire. Conveniently located on the corner of Hill and Watson Street, our park offers easy access to Molong’s charming main street, local shops, and the nearby swimming pool.

Molong Caravan Park features both powered and unpowered sites, perfect for caravans, motorhomes, and tents. Enjoy the convenience of our on-site BBQ facilities and laundry amenities, making your stay as hassle-free as possible. Whether you're here for a short stopover or a longer stay, you'll find the perfect base to explore the surrounding region's rich history, beautiful landscapes, and friendly community

properties.name: Dalmorton Campground
properties.description:
Located in Guy Fawkes River National Park, Dalmorton campground offers a great place for exploring the park or swimming and fishing in Boyd River. 

This non powered campground is suitable for tents, camper trailers, caravans and vehicle based camping. 

Being a remote campground, you will need to be self-sufficient, including your supply of water. Generators are not permitted. Bookings are not available.

properties.name: Dry Tank Campground
properties.description:
Located in Gundabooka National Park, Dry Tank campground offers remote camping for tents, camper trailers, caravans and vehicle-based camping. 

There are toilets and picnic tables available. 

You will need to bring your own water and firewood. Enjoy the walk through mulga woodland to nearby Little Mountain, and the views of Gundabooka Range. Bookings are not available.

properties.name: Dees Corner Campground
properties.description:
Situated in Myall Lakes National Park, Dees Corner campground offers boating, paddling, sailing and fishing. 

There are 16 sites available for tents, camper trailers, caravans, and vehicle-based camping. 

Facilities include BBQ and toilets. You will need to bring your own water. Take care while swimming as there can be strong rips and currents at the beach. Bookings are not availalbe.
properties.fees: (Peak) AUD $10 per adult $5 per child. (Off-peak) AUD $7 per adult $3.50 per child

properties.name: Cutters Campground
properties.description:
Cutters Campground is located in Mebbin National Park. There are 15 campsites suitable for tents, camper trailers and caravans. 

Facilities include picnic tables, BBQ facilities and toilets. 

Water is not available so you need to bring your own supply. Generators are not allowed.
properties.fees: AUD 6 per Adult; AUD 3 per Child; AUD 8 per Vehicle

properties.name: Putty Beach Camping Area
properties.description:
Accommodating 20 sites, Putty Beach campground is the largest of Bouddi National Park's camping areas. Located near Killcare, this Central Coast campground is easily accessed from Gosford and Sydney. The campground sits just steps from the Putty Beach sand and offers good facilities in a natural setting.

Camping type	Tents Only, Don't mind a short walk to tent

What to bring	Drinking water, cooking water

Bookings are required. Book online or call the National Parks Contact Centre on 1300 072 757.
properties.fees: Rates and availability are displayed when making an online booking A minimum nightly rate applies, which includes the first 2 occupants. Minimum stays may apply Nightly rate: $34 (includes 2 people); $17 per additional adult (16+ years); $8.50 per additional child (5–15 years); infants free (0–4 years).

properties.name: Mungo Brush Campground
properties.description:
Mungo Brush campground is a popular and well known campground near Hawks Nest on the north coast. It’s a great place to take your caravan, campervan, trailer or tent. There are tonnes of campsites to choose from – so you’re bound to find one that suits you well.

From the campground there is easy access north to Mungo Rainforest walk and south to Tamboi walking track and Mungo walking track. Being right on the lake means there are great opportunities to go for a kayak or canoe along the lower Myall River to Hawks Nest.

A short walk from the campground leads to the beach, where you go swimming, fishing and sailboarding. If you’re clever enough to catch a fish, you can cook it up for dinner on one of the barbecues in the campground.

There are 78 sites available for tents, camper trailers, caravans and vehicle based camping. 

Facilities include boat ramp, BBQ, picnic tables and toilets. 

Mungo Rainforest walk, Tamboi walking track and Mungo walking track are all in easy access of the campground. Fires are not permitted. Bookings are available.

properties.name: CrossRoads Hotel Van Park
properties.description:
Free van park in the west entrance of Collingullie, next to the hotel. Camp is made up of grass areas, some have water from tap. 

Few trees. Toilets are in the pub garden.

properties.name: Moama North Rest Area
properties.description: Very basic and small rest area located on Cobb Hwy, 10km N of Moama. No facilities, rubbish bins only. Signposted from road.

properties.name: Quambone Primitive Campsite
properties.description: Basic camp area located on Mungie St in Quambone. Has toilets and is next to the swimming pool and tennis courts. You can get keys for pool & courts at Quambone General Store, open 0800-1900 hrs

properties.name: Marthaguy West Rest Area
properties.description: Free rest area located on Oxley Hwy, 22km W of Gilgandra. Covered picnic table, rubbish bin and toilet facilities. Not much shade available.

properties.name: Pagan Creek Bridge Camping
properties.description:
Pagan Creek Bridge camping is located on both sides of the bridge. The river basin is dry most of the time and is therefore suitable for all kinds of vehicles. 

No facilities, SC only. 

There are various options to park your car in the shadow underneath the trees. You will easily find your own little spot, separated from other campers.

properties.name: The Willows Camping Area Yanga National Park
properties.description:
The Willows campground and picnic area is perfect for nature-lovers. Located in Yanga State Conservation Area, this quiet woodland location is a birdwatching paradise, so relax and acquaint yourself with some local feathered friends.

Choose a campsite to set up your tent, trailer, caravan or motor home. Once that’s done, it’s time to explore; wander around the Wilga Woolshed and take in amazing outback views on a bushwalk through the park.

There are barbecues on which you can cook up a feast, or if you’re visiting between April and September you could build a campfire to cook damper and baked potatoes.  Later in the evening, relax around the campfire, under the stars, sharing songs and stories with your fellow campers.

Non-flush toilet. Have some picnic tables and fire camps. Only small bin in the toilet.

properties.name: Teamster Rest Area
properties.description:
Located in the middle of town. 

Self-contained vehicles only

Max stay: 24 hours. 

Picnic area, bins and drinking water available here.

properties.name: Kiga Bore Rest Area
properties.description: Large parking area for SC vehicles. No facilities. Must share with trucks on both sides of the road.

properties.name: Towong Reserve Camping
properties.description:
Towong Reserve Camping Area is a scenic spot along the Upper Murray River, offering both shaded and sunny campsites surrounded by lush greenery. 

While the site itself has no facilities, the nearby town of Corryong is just a short drive away, providing all essential services. The area also features a historic long-drop toilet with a distinctive heavy steel door. 

Please be aware that bridge construction may lead to some closures and detours in the area. This peaceful retreat allows visitors to camp for up to 5 days, with the option to extend their stay with a permit from the local council.

properties.name: Badgerys Lookout
properties.description:
Enjoy breathtaking views of the valley and river below at this serene campsite. 

The rocky ground makes it ideal for campers with a tarp if you're tenting. The site offers excellent fire facilities, including a hot plate, perfect for cooking and staying warm. It's a peaceful spot, with the chance to have the place to yourself. 

There are also picnic areas for a relaxing meal. Although the toilets are basic, the natural beauty makes up for it. 

Keep an eye out for wombats on the drive in! 

While the nearby river is a four-hour round trip, the views and peaceful atmosphere make it a great spot for a quiet getaway.

properties.name: Misty Mountain Campground
properties.description:
Welcome to Misty Mountain Campground.

Centrally located between Nimbin and Murwillumbah in the small town of Kunghur NSW, is the Misty Mountain Campground where you'll see the morning mist roll in, then clear to reveal spectacular days! 

The peace and tranquillity and spectacular scenery makes this the ideal place to relax and unwind or the perfect spot to base yourself while you explore everything the Tweed Shire and the Northern Rivers Region has to offer.

Misty Mountain is suitable for tent campers, caravans and motorhomes.

properties.name: Wylie Baths
properties.description: Wylie's Baths is a dynamic tidal pool environment. It's also a 'living pool' with marine life, a natural rock bottom, octopus, fish, sea urchins, and more!

properties.name: Deano's Smoked Trout Campground
properties.description:
Set amongst rolling hills in the Northern tablelands of NSW, the property consists of 300 acres of pristine countryside. The fish farm itself is around 10 hectares. Powered and unpowered sites available.

Camping in tents is allowed.

Catch some fish and cook it up while you stay!

We now have 8 spring water growing ponds, each 35 metres square. The fish farm itself is stocked primarily with rainbow trout, as well as brown trout and Atlantic salmon.

properties.name: Light to Light Walk
properties.description:
The Light to Light Walk is a stunning coastal hike in Ben Boyd National Park, stretching 30 km from Boyd's Tower to Green Cape Lighthouse. This multi-day trek offers breathtaking views of rugged cliffs, secluded beaches, and wild ocean vistas. 

Along the way, hikers can spot abundant wildlife, including whales during migration season, and explore historical landmarks like the lighthouse and Boyd's Tower. 

Ideal for nature lovers, this walk showcases the untamed beauty of the NSW South Coast.

properties.name: Cullendulla Track and Boardwalk
properties.description:
The Cullendulla Boardwalk and Track is an easy, family-friendly walk that meanders through mangroves and salt marshes along the edge of Batemans Bay. The boardwalk offers stunning views of the Clyde River and is perfect for spotting local wildlife, including fish, crabs, and birdlife. 

This peaceful walk provides a unique perspective on the coastal ecosystem, making it an ideal stop for nature lovers visiting the NSW South Coast

properties.name: The Durras Mountain Walking Track
properties.description:
The Durras Mountain Walking Track in Murramarang National Park is a challenging hike that rewards adventurers with breathtaking coastal and hinterland views. The 7 km loop ascends through lush bushland to the summit of Durras Mountain, offering panoramic vistas over the park's forests, beaches, and the Tasman Sea. 

Ideal for experienced hikers, this track showcases the natural beauty of the NSW South Coast.

properties.name: Bannisters Point Walking Track
properties.description:
The Bannisters Point Walking Track is a scenic coastal walk located near Mollymook on the NSW South Coast. This short but stunning trail offers panoramic ocean views, perfect for spotting dolphins or whales in season. 

The walk takes you through coastal bushland and past the iconic Bannisters Headland, making it a peaceful and picturesque way to explore the coastline.

properties.name: The Coast Track
properties.description:
The Coast track in Sydney's Royal National Park is an epic multi-day walk between Bundeena and Otford. 

Enjoy incredible coastal lookouts, swimming spots, seasonal wildflowers and whale watching along this challenging track.

properties.name: Katoomba Civic Visitor Information Centre
properties.description: Australia's Nationally Accredited Information Centres are staffed by local experts and are your one-stop-shop for maps of the region and information about the best things to see, as well as booking tours and accommodation.

properties.name: Surf Beach Holiday Park Narooma
properties.description: Surf Beach Holiday Park is ideally located on Narooma’s main beach and is situated in the middle of Narooma’s panoramic Golf Course. Providing the closest accommodation to the beach in Narooma, the resort is a great spot for your next holiday.

properties.name: Jacobs Campground
properties.description:
Book a camping stay at Collendina campgrounds in Murray Valley Regional Park at the Murray river, Jacobs campground.

- Campfires are permitted between April and September.
- Collection of deadfall timber is permitted for small campfires only.
- Dogs and domestic pets are permitted everywhere in Murray Valley Regional Park, but they are prohibited in Murray Valley National Park. You can walk and camp with your dog in Murray Valley Regional Park however you will need to keep them on a leash at all times and remember to pick up after them.

properties.name: Winter Canyoning Blue Mountains
properties.description:
Have you ever wanted to try abseiling and canyoning in the Blue Mountains- west of Sydney? Now you can with the safety instruction of experienced guides who can take you out for a full day tour within the Blue Mountains. 

Enjoy up to 5 abseils and canyoning through a narrow, steep but exciting canyon. Spend the morning building up your confidence abseiling rock walls that range from 5 metres to 30 metres high. After lunch, you will travel to the Grose Valley, north of Katoomba for further abseiling and canyoning followed by a relaxing, scenic walk through the mountains. 

All climbing gear is supplied; all you need to bring is your sense of adventure. Tours depart from Katoomba at 8.30am and return at 5pm. This tour runs in the cooler months from May to August so dress comfortably. Book your Blue Mountains Abseil and Canyoning Tour online here!

properties.name: The Fifth Daughter
properties.description:
A Melbourne style cafe in the riverside town of Tocumwal and the perfect spot for breakfast before exploring the area. Close to the cafe is a large lawn area, the famous Murray Cod Sculpture and a modern splash park. 

The Aviation Museum is a relatively new attraction in town where you can learn about this significant, unique and secret part of Australia’s civil and military history.

properties.name: Discovery Parks - Narooma Beach
properties.description:
An idyllic hideaway on the far south coast of New South Wales, Discovery Parks - Narooma Beach (formerly Beachfront Camping Narooma) sits among eucalyptus forest only metres from the sand on Handkerchief Beach. Bordered by pristine beach and stunning coastal walks, nearby lakes, inlets and luminescent waterways are full of marine life and perfect for a swim or a paddle.

Choose from a range of accommodation, relax in the saltwater infinity pool or roll out the picnic rug on lush green grass. Stay in fully self-contained 2 or 3-bedroom cabins and beach houses, one of six safari-style glamping tents or a grassy powered or unpowered site amongst the trees.

properties.name: One Day Thredbo Snow Tour from Sydney
properties.description:
Visit Thredbo’s alpine village this winter ski season on an overnight tour from Sydney. 

Thredbo is the ideal place for first timers or families wanting to learn how to ski or snowboard and when you are in need a break from the ski slopes there are restaurants, bars, cafes and retail shops to explore. 

The overnight tour departs from Haymarket at 11.20pm with comfortable recliner seats for you to snooze. When you wake up, you will be in Jindabyne for a breakfast stop and time to hire equipment before 7.5 hours free time at Thredbo. A

**Highlights**  

-   Season: June to September
-   Thredbo Snow Tour from Sydney
-   Return transfers from central meeting location
-   Skiing or snowboarding
-   7 hours of free time at Thredbo
-   Experience Thredbo's alpine village

properties.name: Bermagui Blue Pool
properties.description: There are dozens of sea-fed rocks pools dotted down the NSW coast, but with its stunningly coloured waters and gorgeous pacific back drop, this might just be our favorite. Whether its for a swim or an insta post, this is a must-see.

properties.name: Kiama Pie Shop
properties.description:
The Kiama Pie Shop is a beloved local gem, known for its delicious, freshly baked pies.

Established in 1968, this charming spot has been serving up savoury and sweet pies for generations, making it a must-visit for foodies traveling along the NSW South Coast. 

Whether you're after a classic meat pie, a gourmet creation, or something sweet like apple pie, the Kiama Pie Shop offers a warm, nostalgic experience with stunning coastal views nearby. 

It's the perfect stop to refuel on your South Coast road trip.

properties.name: Yuin Retreat
properties.description:
The Yuin Retreat is a 2 night, 1 day experience including 2 nights accommodation, meals as indicated and a team of guides offering insights, knowledge and dreamtime stories for the duration of the experience. 

Your lead guide is Dwayne 'Naja' Bannon-Harrison with over 17 years of experience along with 9 generations of cultural teachings passed down. 

Dwayne and the family team at NNCA invite all walks of life onto Yuin country to learn, experience and engage with Yuin Country and culture.

properties.name: Dark Stories Crime Tour
properties.description:
Dark Stories True Crime Tour - retrace the steps of the city's most ruthless. Be seduced by the murky world of fraudsters, adulterers & lordly impersonators. Book your ticket to the city's sinister past.

Take a walk on the criminal side.

Retrace the steps of the city's most ruthless men. Be seduced by the murky world of fraudsters, adulterers and lordly impersonators. Unlock the broken heart of the Tomahawk Murderer. Journey back to the city's dangerous and sinister past. Book your ticket now for a unique investigation into a dark and crime ridden history.

properties.name: Macksville Memorial Aquatic Centre
properties.description:
Parking lot of the local aquatic centre with space for up to five fully self contained vehicles for one night. 

Dump point and public toilets available.

properties.name: Gooloogong Camping Area
properties.description:
Donations welcomed.

You need to book (and pay) with the council for power connection.

Flat sites, plenty of room (22’ Van), power and water, donation camp. Amenities were absolutely spotless with endless hot water. 

One tip, head over the road for a feed at the Pub. Awesome feed at country prices , you won’t be disappointed

properties.name: Norries Head Lookout (Whale Lookout)
properties.description: A short, 5 min walk takes you to the top with nice views of the coast and of migrating whales during the season (May - June & August - November).

properties.name: Eden Lookout
properties.description:
Eden Lookout offers stunning panoramic views over Twofold Bay and the rugged coastline of the NSW South Coast. 

It's a prime location for whale watching, especially during migration season, where you can often spot humpback whales and even orcas as they pass close to shore. 

The lookout also provides sweeping vistas of surrounding forests, beaches, and the historic town of Eden. Whether you're there for wildlife, photography, or simply to take in the breathtaking scenery, Eden Lookout is a must-visit for nature lovers

properties.name: Hillston Caravan Park
properties.description:
Hillston Caravan Park is an ideal stop on the Kidman Way, a terrific route traversing the pristine regional NSW. The Park is situated 6 hours north from Melbourne, 5 hours south from Bourke and just an hour’s drive from the regional centre of Griffith. Hillston Caravan Park offers a warm welcome and a relaxing atmosphere for travellers from near and far.

This tranquil and tidy Park is located within walking distance from the town amenities including cafes, restaurants, supermarket, newsagency, pharmacy and shops. The Park offers accommodation for families, couples, groups of friends, travellers and workers alike. The Park features a range of accommodation to choose from; spacious grassy sites, camping areas and self-contained cabins.

The Park is a great base from which to explore the natural beauty of the Outback, enjoy the green parks on the Lachlan River – a stark contrast to the otherwise arid landscape. Discover the native flora and fauna and take in the rich history of the region.

properties.name: Wonga Wetlands
properties.description:
A sanctuary for birdwatchers, field naturalists, photographers and bushwalking groups, wandering Wonga Wetlands is a fantastic way to wind down and enjoy nature.

Located on the Murray River floodplain, Wonga Wetlands is being gently restored from grazing land using Albury City’s environmentally treated wastewater. An ecosystem of lagoons and billabongs covering 80 hectares of Murray River flood plain, Wonga is home to a variety of wildlife and century old river red gums and an Indigenous scar tree.

In Winter you’ll find the wetlands full to capacity. Pelicans and Swans love this time of year. Over Spring the water starts to recede exposing muddy shorelines which attracts hundreds of wading birds. During Summer the water levels reduce and may dry out completely and as Autumn arrives and temperatures drop the wetlands are again flooded and life begins all over.

properties.name: White Sands Walk
properties.description:
White Sands Walk starts at a boardwalk on Greenfields Beach, just south of Vincentia, crosses a creek and winds south along the bay. Interpretive signs along the track point out significant features of the bay. 

The walk ends at the small village of Hyams Beach.

properties.name: Wagonga Beach and Walks
properties.description:
Take the Wagonga Scenic Drive from the Princes Highway north or south of Narooma, and it will lead you down to Wagonga Inlet and this picturesque picnic area. 

This is an ideal spot to sit back and enjoy a picnic lunch, with spectacular water views. 

There are a couple of short tracks from the picnic tables to enjoy to Bar Beach South, Bar Beach North, and to the seal colony.

properties.name: Wagirra Trail and Yindyamarra Sculpture Walk
properties.description:
Hire a bike or lace up your walking shoes to explore the Murray River pathway, a 15 kilometre (return) trail that links the Wonga Wetlands with the South Albury Trail through blissful riverside parks among soaring red gums. There are plenty of places to stop for a picnic or enjoy the view.

Above all, make a beeline for the five-kilometre Yindyamarra Sculpture Walk between Kremur Street and the Wonga Wetlands. Here, 15 sculptures crafted by Aboriginal artists tell age-old First Nations stories through contemporary art – each comes with an interpretative sign revealing their significance. You can also unlock additional videos via your smartphone.

Pause at Michael Quinn’s Family Gathering, a sculpture symbolising the importance of family unity and Indigenous connection to the land; and Ruth Davys’ Bogon Moth Migration, an installation revealing how Aboriginal communities would feast on these winged delicacies. There is also Tamara Murray’s larger-than-life stainless-steel Reconciliation Shield; Kianna Edwards’ steel and concrete Goanna; and the Maya Fish Trap sculpture, the combined work of Uncle Ken (Tunny) Murray, Darren Wighton and Andom Rendell.

properties.name: Pambula River Walking Track
properties.description:
The Pambula River Walking Track is a scenic, easy-grade walk that follows the tranquil shoreline of the Pambula River in Ben Boyd National Park. 

This 1.2 km trail offers beautiful views of the river's crystal-clear waters, sandy beaches, and surrounding bushland, with opportunities to spot birdlife and marine creatures. 

It also offers a great place to swim, or fish.

Perfect for a relaxing stroll, it’s a great way to explore the natural beauty of the NSW South Coast.

properties.name: Observation Point - Batehaven
properties.description:
Located at Batehaven, Observation Point is a lookout and picnic area with fabulous views overlooking the the beach and out to the beautiful Snapper Island. 

Pause for a bite to eat or just take in the view at this popular picnic spot amongst both tourists and locals. 

Toilet facilities available.

properties.name: Murrays Beach
properties.description: Known as the jewel in the Booderee National Park, Murrays Beach offers swimmers and snorkelers alike, pristine clear waters and pearly white sand. Perfect for families, Murrays Beach is situated in a protected bay which is sheltered by Bowen Island.

properties.name: Mollymook Beach
properties.description: Mollymook Beach sweeps for two kilometres between Bannister Point in the north and the southern headland where the Mollymook golf club is located. Both ends of the beach are patrolled seasonally and the Mollymook Surf Club, which was established in 1933, is located on the southern end.

properties.name: Little Blowhole Kiama
properties.description:
The Little Blowhole is a little bit hard to find, but well worth the effort, situated just off Tingira Crescent three kilometres south of the Kiama Township. 

The spray reaches remarkable heights and can be viewed from a viewing platform or on the rocky foreshore. 

From here, you can also walk around the headland south.

properties.name: Lake Mulwala
properties.description:
Experience the idyllic waterways North of the Murray. Lake Mulwala is an unforgettable sight with its majestic and ghostly river red gums and offers a range of activities for visitors and locals alike.

Water-based activities are a focal point of the bustling country town of Mulwala, located three hours from Melbourne. Enjoy popular activities including boating, waterskiing, kayaking, windsurfing and stand-up paddleboarding. They offer lessons for beginners and competitions for experts. Board a paddle steamer cruise or try out a barbeque boat with friends and family. Book a guided fishing tour with experts or set up camp along the banks with your fishing gear to catch the famed Murray Cod.

Both sides of the lake have attractive foreshores that provide a year-round recreation area, including picnic and barbecue facilities, walking tracks, waterslides, playgrounds, a skate park, swimming pools and a splash park. There's more to life – and more to discover – on the waterways North of the Murray.

For the keen angler, species found in the area include Murray Cod, Trout Cod, Golden Perch (Yellow Belly), Silver Perch, and Murray Crayfish. For recreational fishing in the Murray River, a NSW recreational fishing licence is required.

properties.name: Hastings Point Beach
properties.description:
Hastings Point is the smallest coastal settlement of New South Wales Tweed Shire; the "Jewel of the Tweed", surrounded by national park, the hamlet is nestled between the ocean on its east and a beautiful but delicate estuary on its west.

Back from the beach, a network of creeks and estuaries guarantee endless water play and moments of calm and you can cue all the anticipated coastal holiday highlights of fishing, low-tide rock pools, river kayaking, crisp fish and chips, laid-back caravan parks, barbecues and most other things sure to be on your relaxed getaway checklist.

properties.name: Glasshouse Rocks and Pillow Lava
properties.description:
Surf Beach, Narooma has two amazing sites of ancient geological significance and beauty at either end of the sandy beach. At the southern end lie the imposing Glasshouse Rocks; a photographers dream and dated between 510 and 440 million years old. They are possibly the most photographed rocks along the Eurobodalla coastline.

At the northern end of the beach there is a display of igneous pillow lava which formed through the lava flow of a submarine volcano.

How to get there: At low tide you can walk to the rocks from Surf Beach carpark, around the headland to Glasshouse Rocks. Here you will see more of the rocks, which are impressive in stature. The pillow lava display is easily accessed along the beach, approximately 300m north of the carpark.

For headland views, follow Glasshouse Rocks Road and veer left onto Cemetery Road and the Narooma Cemetery carpark. Head past the cemetery on foot towards the white fence.

To access the beach, you can walk around the fence into bush to access a track (no signs). At the fork in the trail veer left down a fairly steep dirt track. At the beach head south to reach Glasshouse Rocks.

Exercise caution! The track is not suitable for the mobility impaired, elderly or young children and is not signposted.

properties.name: Careys Cave
properties.description:
The gem of Wee Jasper.

Travelling to Wee Jasper is a journey through one of the most diverse geological landscapes in Australia. The road passes through a range of volcanic and sedimentary rocks with a mix of broad acre and grazing rural properties. 

Careys Cave is located in the beautiful Wee Jasper valley, about 50 kilometres from Yass and 80 kilometres from Canberra.

Set in a spectacular limestone landscape, Careys Cave features beautiful, naturally sculpted rock and a wealth of different cave formations. Access is down a flight of 30 steps, after which floors are mostly level with well-trodden and lit paths passing through various chambers. 

Suitable for all ages, two tours are on offer, covering different parts of the cave system, depending on group size.

properties.name: Burrinjuck Dam
properties.description:
Originally the Aboriginal Booren Yiack, then Barren Jack and now Burrinjuck, the name has become renowned as a nature and water wonderland on the headwaters of the Murrumbidgee River 60 kilometres from Yass.

Constructed over more than 20 years, the Burrinjuck Dam remains one of the world's largest irrigation dams and is a perfect place for a swim or fish.

properties.name: Munyunga Waraga Dhugan Walking Trail
properties.description: Munyunga Waraga Dhugan Walking Trail is a moderate 5.4-kilometre loop trail in Booderee National Park, New South Wales. It takes in stunning views of Jervis Bay, Bowen Island, and the Tasman Sea, as well as coastal heathland, native forest, and a beautiful beach. The trail is also home to a variety of wildlife, including wallabies, birds, and even the endangered eastern bristlebird.

properties.name: Cape St George Lighthouse
properties.description:
The Cape St George Lighthouse is a ruined lighthouse located in Booderee National Park, Jervis Bay, New South Wales, Australia. It was built in 1860 and decommissioned in 1899. The lighthouse was constructed of sandstone blocks quarried near the present-day Jervis Bay village. It was a three-story building with eight rooms at ground level. The tower was 61 feet (18.5 meters) high. 

The lighthouse was built to mark the southern entrance to Jervis Bay. It was an important navigational aid for ships sailing between Sydney and Melbourne. However, the lighthouse was located on a high cliff, and it was often obscured by fog. This led to a number of shipwrecks in the area. 

The lighthouse was decommissioned in 1899 and replaced by the Point Perpendicular Lighthouse. The Cape St George Lighthouse was demolished in the early 1920s. However, the ruins of the lighthouse still remain today.

properties.name: Green Patch Camping Ground
properties.description:
In close proximity to Green Patch beach, the picturesque lagoon, and surrounded by trees and bushland, the natural setting and discrete campsites at Green Patch are ideal for families and small groups. Browse the images above to preview the Green Patch experience.

Sites are available in standard and large sizes and as well as drive-in or walk-in. Sheltered barbeques, tables and seating, abundant and amenities and a large day use area make this a Booderee hot spot. Don’t forget the frisbee!

properties.name: Figure 8 Pools
properties.description:
Figure Eight Pools is a cluster of naturally formed rockpools tucked between coastal headlands in Sydney’s Royal National Park. 

It's a difficult walk to get there and back, and it's only safe at low tide with calm, flat surf conditions.

properties.name: Murraybank Caravan Park
properties.description:
The park in situated just out of the Barmah and Millewa National Parks – home to the world’s biggest single stand of River Redgum.

Murraybank Caravan Park is approximately 20 minutes drive from the rural township of Mathoura, which is situated midway between Echuca-Moama and Deniliquin.

Murraybank Caravan Park is a family-friendly and dog-friendly (on leash) caravan park offering caravan and camping sites, both powered and unpowered. There are a limited number of sites on the river banks at the top end of the park, as well as a large, flat grassed area at the other end of the park.

properties.name: Cave Beach Camping Area
properties.description:
The Cave Beach camping area is located in beautiful Booderee National Park at Jervis Bay. Cave Beach is listed by Australian Geographic as one of the best secluded beach camping areas in Australia. 

Booderee offers a wide range of activities in a pristine natural setting, including swimming, fishing and snorkelling.

properties.name: Bristol Point Camping Area
properties.description: The Bristol Point camping area is located in beautiful Booderee National Park

properties.name: Quandialla Showgrounds
properties.description: The Quandialla Showgrounds has powered and non-powered sites available for caravans, and tents. Facilities include toilets and showers. Bookings required.

properties.name: Werris Creek Campground
properties.description:
Free camp offered by the local council.

It has;

- free hot showers
- toilets
- gas BBQ 
- plenty of space

This freedom camping area is unmanned, but does have a donation box at the site.  These funds are then used for the maintenance of each of these areas and your donations are very much appreciated by the outlying villages as well as your patronage in these communities.

properties.name: Denman Van Village
properties.description:
Denman Van Village is a quiet and shady park, away from the main highway, in a bushland setting with an abundance of trees for shade and native bird life for the keen bird watcher, travellers often call our place an oasis.

The Denman Van Village features 59 fully-serviced sites with bitumen roadways, cottage, new and renovated cabins, caravan/camper van and camping sites all with ensuites. 

Facilities also include a free gas barbecue, CCTV, free WiFi, EV chargers, uutdoor fire pit, guest laundry and dump point.

properties.name: Billy Grace Wee Jasper Reserve
properties.description:
A tranquil paradise where you can pick your spot, set up, and just take in the nature that abounds around you, a holiday at Billy Grace Reserve is one for the soul. This reserve features large flat unpowered sites, perfect for any camping or caravanning setup, and we can accommodate extra-large rigs. 

 Billy Grace Reserve is the main reserve within Wee Jasper, and features the main office and kiosk,
hot showers, flushing toilets and a children's playground.

There is also a large flat area nearer the entrance, perfect for larger groups like school tours, caving groups, and campouts.

Billy Grace Reserve is situated right on the Goodradigbee River where it meets Wee Jasper Creek, and it is also the largest reserve at Wee Jasper. With its facilities and convenience, Billy Grace is the perfect place for first-time campers or young families as there are picnic tables and public barbeques available for use.

As the main hub of the reserves, Billy Grace Reserve has plenty of shade and resources including the caravanning/RV dump point and rubbish compound.

properties.name: Purtle Park Adventure Playground
properties.description:
Head to Purtle Park Adventure Playground on the banks of Lake Mulwala for an outing the whole family can enjoy. This family-friendly park contains a free-standing all-abilities play system with attractive modern designs, overlooking the water. 

The park encourages risk-taking and problem solving for older children, with sky cabins and swaying walkways 5 metres above the ground. Officially opened in December 2020, a toddler play area, fenced play area, water and vertical play areas, a basket swing, the pelican nest and a flying fox are among the many fun attractions to be found at the park. 

Pack a picnic, make use of the undercover barbecue facilities, or make the short walk to one of the delicious bakeries or cafes found North of the Murray. This is where there's more to life.

properties.name: Gundaroo Sport & Recreation Ground
properties.description:
This is a large free camp area in Gundaroo with lots of space to camp, an amenities block with toilets and showers and a playground. 

Entry on Cork St, accessible for all vehicle types.
